Chapter One: News of the Monasteries

Dayr Ablaq (The Piebald Monastery)
Dayr al-Ablaq: A monastery in Ahwaz [Ahvaz, Iran], then in Kawara in the district of Ardashir-Khwarrah [Firuzabad, Iran]. Ahmed bin Muhammad bin al-Hasan al-Asadi and Amr bin Abdullah al-Ataki told me, saying: Al-Riyashi told us: That Haritha bin Badr was in Kawara for recreation. Al-Ataki said in his report from Abu Ubaidah—which al-Asadi did not say, nor did al-Riyashi go beyond it—he said: Haritha was in Kawara of Ardashir-Khwarrah and said:
'Did you not see that Haritha bin Badr...
stayed at Dayr Ablaq in Kawara?'
Then he said to the soldiers who were with him: "Whoever completes this verse, for him is a judgment (reward)." A man among them said: "I will complete it, on the condition that you grant me safety from your anger, make me your messenger to Basra [Basra, Iraq], and seek my discharge from the Emir." He said: "That is yours." Then he repeated the recitation of the verse to him, and the man said:
'Residing there drinking pure reddish wine...
Whenever I said it would knock him down, he spun around.'
Haritha said to him: "You have your condition, though if you had said something that pleased us, we would have pleased you." Al-Mada'ini recounted saying: He drank the morning draught in Dayr al-Ablaq with a group of his companions, and when he became intoxicated, he said:
'My day at Dayr al-Ablaq, the unique...
You are nothing but the Garden of Eternity!'
'In it and the likes of it, Abu al-Hindi...
Never ceased to drive the white camels.'

Dayr al-A'la (The Upper Monastery)
Dayr al-A'la in Mosul [Mosul, Iraq]. Beneath the monastery was a large spring known today as Ain Kibrit (Sulfur Spring). Yakut said about it that it appeared under Dayr al-A'la in the year 301 AH (913 AD), and that it contains several minerals: sulfur, marcasite, and vitriol. Professor Gurgis Awad said: The water of this spring is cold in all seasons of the year, and people visit it in summer to bathe in its water, which benefits those among them afflicted with certain skin diseases. Some of them drink a little of its water to relieve the heat of their stomachs.
- The Palm Sunday (Sha'anin) in this monastery is beautiful; people go out to it and stay there for days drinking. Whatever governors passed through Mosul would stay there.
- Beside the monastery is the shrine of Amr bin al-Hamq al-Khuza'i, who was a Companion from the companions of Ali bin Abi Talib.
- Sa'id al-Khalidi said regarding it:
'A moon at the Upper Monastery of Mosul...
I am his slave and his love is my master.'
'He kissed the cross, so I said out of envy...
My mouth was more deserving of the beloved's kiss.'
Dayr al-A'la: This monastery is in Mosul at its highest point, overlooking the Tigris and the Zab. It is a large, populated monastery, cited as an example for the fineness of its air and the beauty of its view. It is said that the Christians have no monastery like it due to the gospels and places of worship it contains.
Muhammad bin Mazid told me, saying: Hammad bin Ishaq told us, saying: Ahmad bin Sadaqa told me, saying: We went out with Al-Ma'mun, and we stopped at Dayr al-A'la in Mosul due to its pleasantness and integrity. The festival of Palm Sunday arrived, so Al-Ma'mun sat in a spot within it that was beautiful and overlooked the Tigris, the desert, and the orchards, and from which one could see those entering the monastery. The monastery was decorated that day in the finest attire. Its monks and priests came out to the altar, and around them were their young men with censers in their hands, wearing crosses and draped in embroidered sashes. Al-Ma'mun saw that and found it beautiful. Then the people dispersed to their cells and their communion. Those slave girls and boys who were with them turned towards Al-Ma'mun, each holding a gift of the aromatic plants of their season, and a group of them holding cups containing types of drink. He drew them near and began taking a greeting from this one and that one, having been captivated by what he saw of them—and there was none among us who was not in this state. During all this, he was drinking while music was playing. Then he ordered the slave girls with him who wore the zunnar (waist sash) to be brought out. Twenty slave girls came out to him, looking like full moons, wearing brocade, with gold crosses on their necks, holding palm leaves and olives in their hands. He said: "O Ahmad, I have composed verses about these, so sing them to me," which are:
'Gazelles like dinars (gold coins)...
Beautiful in the chambers.'
'Palm Sunday has revealed them...
To us in the zunnars (sashes).'
'And they have curled sidelocks...
Like the tails of starlings.'
'And they approached with waists...
Like the waists of wasps.'
Then he brought out Ni'am, his slave girl, who was a servant, and she sang:
'You claimed that I was unjust so you abandoned me...
And you shot into my liver with a piercing arrow.'
'Yes, I wronged you, so forgive and overlook...
This is the station of the seeker of refuge, the shelterer.'
'This is the station of a youth harmed by passion...
With wounded eyelids, seeking refuge in the beauty of your face.'
'And you have taken from my heart its familiarity...
May Allah not paralyze the hand of that taker.'

He was moved and drank, and asked for the song to be repeated several times. Then he said to Al-Yazidi: "Have you seen anything better than what we are in?" He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful, that you thank the One who granted you this so He may increase it for you and preserve it for you." He said: "May Allah bless you, for you have reminded in the place of remembrance." Then he ordered thirty thousand dirhams and gave it as charity immediately.

Dayr al-Anwar (Monastery of Lights)
Dayr al-Anwar: Near Amorium [Ammuriya, Turkey] in the land of the Romans (Byzantines). Abu Bakr Muhammad bin al-Qasim al-Anbari said: I left Anbar [Al-Anbar, Iraq] on some of my travels to Amorium in the land of the Romans. On the way, I stayed at a monastery called Dayr al-Anwar in a village near Amorium. The master of the monastery, the leader of the monks there, came out to me—his name was Abdul-Masih. He brought me into the monastery, and I found forty monks inside. They honored me that night with good hospitality. Then I departed from them the next day, having seen such diligence and worship from them as I had never seen from anyone else. I accomplished my purpose in Amorium and returned to Anbar. When the following year came, I performed Hajj. While I was circumambulating the Noble House (Kaaba), I saw Abdul-Masih the monk also circumambulating, accompanied by five of his companion monks. When I confirmed his identity, I approached him and said to him:
- "Are you Abdul-Masih (Servant of the Messiah) the monk?"
- He said: "Nay, I am Abdullah (Servant of Allah), the seeker of Allah's pardon."
I began kissing his grey hair and weeping, then I took his hand and moved to the side of the Sanctuary. I said to him: "By the One who guided you, will you not tell me the reason for your Islam?"
He said: It was a wonder! A group of Muslim ascetics and worshippers passed by the village I was in. They sent a young man among them to buy food for them. He saw in the market a Christian girl selling bread, and she was one of the most beautiful women and loveliest in form. When he looked at her, he was captivated by her and fell to his face, fainting. When he recovered, he returned to his companions and informed them of what befell him, saying to them:
- "Go about your business, for I am not going with you."
They rebuked him and preached to him, but he paid no attention to them. So they departed and left him. He entered the village and sat at the door of that woman's shop. She asked him about his need, and he told her that he was in love with her. She turned away from him. He remained in his place for three days eating no food, staring at her face. When she saw that he would not leave her, she went to her family and neighbors and told them. They set the boys upon him to stone him. They stoned him until they crushed his head, smashed his face, and bloodied his ribs, yet he still would not leave. The people of the village resolved to kill him. A man among them came to me and told me of his condition. I went out to him and saw him lying down. I wiped the blood from his face, carried him to the monastery, and treated his wounds. He stayed with me for fourteen days. When he was able to walk, he left the monastery, came to the door of the woman's shop, and sat looking at her. When she saw him, she stood up to him and said:
- "By Allah, I have pitied you. Will you enter my religion so that I may marry you?"
He said: "Allah forbid that I shed the religion of Monotheism and enter the religion of polytheism."
She said:
- "Stand and enter my house with me, satisfy your desire with me, and leave guided."
He said: "I am not one to waste the worship of twelve years for the lust of a single moment!"
She said:
- "Then leave me."
He said: "My heart does not obey me."
She turned her face away from him. The boys noticed him and advanced upon him, stoning him. He fell on his face saying:
- "Indeed, my protector is Allah, who has sent down the Book; and He is an ally to the righteous." I left the monastery and came to him, chasing the boys away from him. I lifted his head from the ground and heard him say:
- "O Allah, unite me and her in Paradise." I carried him to the monastery, but he died before I reached it with him. I took him out of the village, dug a grave for him, and buried him. When night came and half of it had passed, that woman screamed a great scream in her bed. The people of the village gathered to her and asked her about her story. She said:

- "While I was sleeping, that Muslim man entered upon me, took my hand, and took me to Paradise. When he brought me to its gate, its keeper prevented me from entering, saying that it is forbidden to disbelievers. So I accepted Islam at his hand and entered Paradise with him. I saw therein palaces and trees that I cannot describe well to you. Then he took me to a palace of jewels and said: 'This palace is for me and you, and I will not enter it except with you. In five nights you will be with me in it, if Allah Almighty wills.' Then he reached his hand to a tree at the gate of the palace and plucked two apples from it, saying: 'Eat this one, and hide the other until the monks see it.' I ate the apple and never tasted anything better. Then he took my hand and brought me out until I reached my house." Then she took out the apple from her pocket, and it shone in the darkness of the night as if it were a brilliant star. They brought the woman to us at the monastery with the apple. We had never seen anything like it among the fruits of Paradise. I took a knife and divided it according to the number of my companions. We never saw anything more delicious than its taste nor better than its scent. We said: "Perhaps a devil appeared to her to seduce her from her religion." Her family took her and left. Then she abstained from eating and drinking. When it was the fifth night, she rose from her bed, left her house, and went to his grave. She threw herself upon it and died, and no one from her family knew of her. When it was morning, two Muslim sheikhs wearing clothes of hair (wool) approached the village, accompanied by two women dressed similarly. They said: "Allah has a female saint (Waliyah) among you who has died as a Muslim, and we will take charge of her, not you." The people of the village sought the woman and found her dead upon the grave. They said:
- "This is our companion who died in our religion, and we will take charge of her." The dispute and conflict intensified between them. One of the two sheikhs said: "The sign of her Islam is that the monks of the monastery 'the forty' should gather and pull her from the grave. If she comes with them, she is a Christian. Then one of us will step forward and pull her; if she is pulled with him, she is a Muslim." The people of the village agreed to this. The forty monks of the monastery gathered, and we came to her to carry her, but we could not. We tied a thick rope around her waist, and the 'forty monks' pulled all together, but the rope broke, and she did not move. The villagers stepped forward and did the same, but she did not move from her place. When we were unable to move her by any trick, we said to one of the sheikhs: "You step forward and carry her." He stepped forward to her, pulled her by his cloak, and said: "In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, upon the religion of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him." Then he carried her in his lap and went with her to a cave there. He placed her in it, and the two women came and washed and shrouded her. Then the two sheikhs carried her, prayed over her, and we buried her next to the grave of that ascetic. We departed having witnessed all of this. When we were alone with each other, we said: "The truth is more worthy of being followed, and the truth has become clear to us by witnessing and sight. There is no proof of the validity of the religion of Islam clearer to us than what we have seen." Then I accepted Islam, and the 'forty' monks of the monastery and all the people of the village accepted Islam. Then we sent to the land of "Al-Jazira" requesting a knowledgeable jurist to teach us the laws of Islam and the rulings of the religion. A righteous jurist came to us and taught us the method of worship and the rulings of Islam, and we are today in great goodness. To Allah belongs the praise and the favor for that.

Dayr Bawlus (Paul's Monastery)
Dayr Bawlus in Ramla [Ramla, Palestine/Israel]. Abu al-Faraj said: It is in the district of Ramla. Al-Halabi told me, saying: My father told me: I stayed with Al-Fadl bin Ismail bin Salih bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Abbas at Dayr Bawlus while we were going out towards Ramla. He saw a beautiful girl there, the daughter of a priest there. She served him for three days and gave him aged wine to drink. When he wanted to depart, he gave her ten dinars and said on his way:
'Peace of Allah be upon you, O monastery, from a youth...
In whose soul is a long yearning for you.'
'May a heavy downpour from the rise of Arcturus never cease...
Upon you, quenching your soil.'
'May a cloud guaranteeing the revival of the gardens...
Give you a second drink, time after time.'
'When its tears water a land, a view appears...
That is beautiful to the eyes of the beholders.'
'Oh, many a dark night I have cut through...
With no companion with me but the sword.'
'And chilled wine, for which I lit for my companions...
Lamps whose wicks never fade.'
'A slender, tender girl distracts me with wine...
Upon whom there seems to be a trustee over hearts.'
'Deaths roam among them when...
Her glances begin roaming among hearts.'
'O daughter of the monastery's priest, my heart is obsessed...
With you, and my body, since you became distant, is ailing.'
And regarding it, Abu Sha's says:

'O Dayr Yunus, may the rain clouds water your courtyard...
Until it is seen looking with blossoms, smiling.'
'No water in the heat of summer cured a thirst...
As your cold water cured the heat of my heart.'
'And no sorrowful one with illness ever settled in you...
Except that illness dissolved away from him.'
'I seek forgiveness from Allah; how many a coquettish one have I had in you...
Because of whom the pen ran against me in your quarters.'
He also says:
'Do not turn away from the daughter of the vine (wine)...
For my father's sake! For in it is the health of the body!'
'If there were no relief in drinking it...
Except the deliverance from the hand of worry!'
Abu Sha's also says:
'O blamer, there is no way against the likes of me...
And your blaming regarding wine is impossible.'
'Is not my mount the waist of a boy...
And the saddle of my fingertips a chilled cup?'
'If the daughters of the vine are my drink...
And the qibla of my face is the beautiful face.'
'I am safe with these two from the consequence of the nights...
And what the blamer reports is easy for me!'

Dayr al-Thaalib (The Foxes' Monastery)
- Al-Shabushti said: This monastery is in Baghdad [Baghdad, Iraq], on the western side of it, at the place known as Bab al-Hadid (The Iron Gate). The people of Baghdad visit it and recreate in it, and it is hardly ever empty of a visitor or a knocker. It has a festival in which no one from the Christians or Muslims stays behind. Bab al-Hadid is the most populated place in Baghdad and the most pleasant: because of the orchards, trees, palms, and aromatic plants it contains, and for its central location in the city and proximity to everyone. So it is not devoid of idle people, nor is it missed by people of music and pleasures. Its spots are forever populated, and its grounds are packed with picnickers.
- Al-Biruni mentioned that the festival of Dayr al-Thaalib is the last Saturday of September, unless the first of October of the coming year is a Sunday, in which case the festival is delayed to it and exits September. Thus that year is stripped (of the festival), and it repeats in the coming year twice: at its beginning and its end.
- Yakut said that it is: A famous monastery, between it and Baghdad is two miles or less, in the district of Nahr Isa, on the road to Sarsar. I saw it myself, and near it is a village called Al-Harithiya.
- Muhammad bin Umar Ibn Dehqana al-Hashimi has verses of poetry in which the name of the monastery appears, including:
'Dayr al-Thaalib, the haunt of error...
And the place of every gazelle (sun) and gazelle (boy/girl).'
- Among the earliest to mention this monastery is Khalifa bin Khayyat. He mentioned it in the events of the year 127 AH, before the establishment of the city of Baghdad. He said in a long report: Al-Dahhak bin Qays advanced from Al-Mada'in intending Kufa, so he camped at Dayr al-Thaalib with three thousand, and the exaggerator says: with four thousand.
- In the book "Al-Hawadith al-Jami'ah" (The Comprehensive Events), there is a mention of this monastery. It said in the events of the year 683 AH:
- In this year, the Tigris rose greatly, and several areas in the western side of Baghdad flooded, and it reached the domes of Dayr al-Thaalib.
- Sibt Ibn al-Ta'awidhi, the famous poet (583 AH), visited this monastery on its feast day and saw a handsome deacon there, so he improvised about him:
'And a gazelle I became attached to...
On the day of Dayr al-Thaalib.'
'From the gazelles of the detached sand...
Strutting in the garb of a monk.'
'He tightened his zunnar so he dissolved...
The knots of the religious schools.'
- Father Anastas Marie al-Karmali mentioned that the remains of Dayr al-Thaalib are known today as Ain al-Sanam.
- Father Louis Cheikho favored the view that "Dayr al-Thaalib is attributed, as we think, to the Banu Tha'labah who converted to Christianity, close to Baghdad near Al-Harithiya."
- Dr. Abdul Latif al-Rawi supported him in this preference. See: Iraqi Society in the Poetry of the Fourth Century AH, 282. And see: Masalik al-Absar 1-277, 571.

Dayr al-Thaalib near Baghdad, in the district of Nahr Isa, at the place known as Bab al-Hadid.
- I and Abu al-Fath Ahmad bin Ibrahim bin Ali bin Isa, may Allah have mercy on him, went out to Dayr al-Thaalib on a day in the year 355 AH for recreation and to witness the gathering of Christians there, and to drink by the Yazdegerd River which flows at the gate of this monastery. While we were touring the monastery, accompanied by a group of the children of Christian scribes and their youths, suddenly a young girl, like an engraved dinar as they say, swaying and bending like a basil branch in the north breeze, struck her hand upon Abu al-Fath's hand and said: "O my master, come read this poetry written on the wall of the witness room." So we went with her, and we were filled with such joy because of her, her charm, and the beauty of her speech that only Allah knows. When we entered the room, she revealed a forearm like silver and pointed to the spot, and there was written:

'She went out on the day of her festival...
In the clothes of the nuns.'
'So she captivated with her strutting...
Every comer and goer.'
'For my misery I saw her...
On the day of Dayr al-Thaalib.'
'Swaying among women...
A buxom girl among buxom girls.'
'She is among them like the...
Full moon among the stars.'
We said to her: "By Allah, you are the one intended by the meaning of these verses." We did not doubt that she wrote the verses, and she did not leave us for the rest of our day. I composed these verses about her and recited them to her, and she rejoiced:
'A slender-waisted one passed by us in the monastery...
Bewitching the viewer, captivating.'
'The monks brought her out from her seclusion...
To honor the monastery and its monks.'
'She passed by us swaying in her walk...
As if her stature was a ben tree.'
'A wind blew on her so she leaned with it...
Just as the branch of basil bends.'
'She enslaved my heart and stirred for it...
Its ancient sorrows and griefs.'
Between her and Abu al-Fath, an intimacy developed after that. Then he left for al-Sham (Syria) and died there, and I know no news of her after that.

Dayr al-Jathaliq (The Catholicos Monastery)
Dayr al-Jathaliq
- There are two monasteries bearing the same name:
- The first: An old monastery at the head of the border between Al-Sawad and the land of Takrit [Tikrit, Iraq].
- The second: Was in the west of the city of Baghdad. Al-Shabushti described it saying: This monastery is near Bab al-Hadid. It is a large, beautiful, pleasant monastery, surrounded by orchards, trees, and aromatic plants. It parallels Dayr al-Thaalib in pleasantness, goodness, and the development of the location, because they are in one spot.
- In some sources, this Dayr al-Jathaliq was located on the Rufayl River, one of the old rivers of Baghdad in the days of the Abbasids; its intake was from the Isa River and its outlet into the Tigris at the bridge.
- The Baghdadi Dayr al-Jathaliq was also called "Dayr Klilishu," which is a Syriac word meaning "Wreath of Jesus."
- It is understood from historical texts that Dayr al-Jathaliq is an ancient monastery whose construction dates back to before the founding of Baghdad, indeed to before the appearance of Islam.
