Dayr al-Jathaliq near Baghdad. A monastery of old construction, with a spacious courtyard from the district of Maskin, near Baghdad on the west of the Tigris in the width of Harbi. It is at the head of the border between Al-Sawad and the land of Takrit. At it was the war between Abd al-Malik bin Marwan and Mus'ab bin al-Zubayr, and at it Mus'ab bin al-Zubayr was killed. Ubayd Allah bin Qays al-Ruqayyat said eulogizing him:
'Indeed, a slain man residing at Dayr al-Jathaliq...
Has bequeathed sorrow and humiliation to the two cities (Kufa and Basra).'
'Bakr bin Wa'il did not fight for the sake of Allah...
Nor was Tamim truthful at the encounter.'
'If only there had been among Qays, circling around him...
Battalions whose fervor boils and endures.'
'But he wasted the time, and there was not...
A generous Mudarite with him on that day.'
'May Allah repay a Kufan with blame for that...
And their Basran, for the generous one is generous.'
- My uncle told me from Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin Mahrawayh, from Ali bin Abdullah bin Sa'd who said: Bakr bin Kharijah was in love with a Christian boy called Isa bin al-Bara al-Abbadi al-Sayrafi. He has a poem in couplets about him in which he mentions the Christians, their laws, and their festivals, names their monasteries, and favors them. He said: And I was told by one who witnessed Di'bil when he recited his saying about Isa bin al-Bara al-Abbadi:
'His zunnar is knotted at his waist...
As if it is cut from my liver.'
Di'bil said: Allah knows I have never envied anyone as I envied Bakr for these two verses! Bakr bin Kharijah said about Isa bin al-Bara al-Abbadi:
'So by the Gospel recited by sheikhs...
Monks at the monastery of "Al-Jathaliq".'
'And by the Eucharist and the crosses, unless...
You have pity on my sick, yearning heart.'
'Grant me sanctuary, I have died before you from my worries...
And guide me to the path of the road.'
'For the faces of my affair have narrowed upon me...
And you are the one sought for refuge from the strait.'
Bakr bin Kharijah used to stay often at this monastery, famous for drinking in it, out of infatuation with this Christian boy. About him, he says a beautiful Urjuza (poem) including his saying:
'From a distant lover whose passion is near...
Speaking with tears, silent of tongue.'
'Bound of heart, free of body...
Tormented by rejection and abandonment.'
'Without a sin his hands earned...
Except a passion his eyes revealed.'

'Longing for the sight of the one who made him miserable...
As if he healed him who afflicted him.'
'Oh woe to him, what a lover encounters...
From pouring tears that do not cease.'
'He melted until he almost disappeared from love...
And became finer than fine thought regarding him.'
'Nothing remained in him but an eye weeping...
With tears like the arrangement of a string.'
'As if it resembles the rain of the sky...
Extinguishing the fires of passion and kindling them.'
'To a gazelle from the children of the Christians...
The fuzz of his cheeks captivated the virgins.'
'Leaving the minds of mankind bewildered...
Captives in the noose of love for him.'
'A white antelope at the monastery of the Romans aimed at killing me...
With a dark eye, not from kohl.'
'And a forelock by which my mind flew away...
And beautiful coquetry and ugly deed.'
'Here I am, cut from his stature...
And the tear from my cheek has a trench for him.'
'What harm would it do the one by whom my heart is supported...
If avoidance did not disturb his purity?'
'I wish I were a cross for him...
So I would be forever near him.'
'Seeing beauty and smelling perfume...
Fearing neither slanderer nor watcher.'
'Or I wish I were an offering for him...
Kissing the mouth and fingertips from him.'
'Or I were a Catholicos or a Metropolitan...
So that he would see obedience to me as faith.'
'Or I wish I were a zunnar for him...
My waist turning with him wherever he turned.'
'Until when the night folds the day...
I become a waist-wrapper for him under the darkness.'
'I wish I were an amulet on his chest...
Or wine he drinks, delicious.'
'Or a suit he wears, cut...
Not discarded when it wears out.'
'I wish I were a scripture for Amr...
Or a pen with which he writes what he composed.'
'Of beautiful poems he has classified...
For I have enough of some of this.'
'Oh for the one who exhausted me with his beauty...
And stripped away my patience and clothed me in emaciation.'
'A gazelle on distance and nearness...
Took the place of the soul in my body.'
'Oh my liver from his reddened cheek...
Oh my sadness from his gap-toothed smile.'
'Nothing like his black eye...
Is more removing of piety and restraint.'
'To you I complain, O gazelle of intimacy...
O you whose face is my crescent and my sun.'
'What loneliness I have after intimacy...
The soul is not killed except by the soul.'
'Here I am drowning in the sea of passion...
Drunk from your love, I do not sober up.'
'Burning, while no fire touched me...
The enemy and the friend have mercy on me.'
And he says in it:
'O Amr, I adjure you by the Messiah...
Will you not hear the speech of an advisor?'
'Expressing a heart that is wounded for him...
Not resting from love.'
'O Amr, by the truth of the Divinity (Lahut)...
And the Spirit, the Holy Spirit, and the Humanity (Nasut).'
'That one who was singled out with descriptions...
Speaking in the cradle and with silence.'
'By the right of whoever is in the lofty hermitages...
Of one prostrating to his Lord and bowing.'
'Weeping when every sleeper sleeps...
Out of fear of Allah with flowing tears.'
Then he swears to him by every oath the Christians know and says:
'Will you not look, O prince of my affair...
Seeking the great reward regarding me?!'

Dayr al-Jamajim (The Monastery of Skulls)
Dayr al-Jamajim in Kufa [Kufa, Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: It is a monastery on the outskirts of Kufa, on the land road taken to Basra. At it occurred the battle between Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf and Abd al-Rahman bin Muhammad bin al-Ash'ath. That was because Ibn al-Ash'ath, when he saw the large number of his army in Basra, and Al-Hajjaj had confronted him there, left intending for Kufa. He saw that its people were more obedient to him than the people of Basra due to their hatred of Al-Hajjaj, and because he would find many supporters among his clans and clients there. So he marched to it, and Al-Hajjaj marched parallel to him. Ibn al-Ash'ath camped at Dayr al-Jamajim, and Al-Hajjaj camped opposite him at Dayr Qurra. War broke out between them, then Ibn al-Ash'ath was defeated and returned to Basra. The poets have mentioned Dayr al-Jamajim often. Jarir said mocking Al-Farazdaq:
'Did you not witness Al-Jawnayn, the Pass, and Al-Safa...
And the attacks of Qays on the day of Dayr al-Jamajim?'
'You incite, O son of the blacksmith, Qays so they might make...
For your people a day like the day of Al-Araqum.'
'With the sword of Abu Raghwan, the sword of Mujashi'...
You struck, but you did not strike with the sword of Ibn Zalim.'
'You struck with it in the presence of the Imam, so your hands...
Trembled, and they said: A novelty (prophet), not a sharp sword.'
Regarding this monastery, Al-Dahhak al-Yarbou'i says:
'If Al-Hajjaj perishes, then the garrison city is our garrison city...
Otherwise, our abode is at Dayr al-Jamajim.'
'If you bring out Sufyan, we bring out to you...
Abu Hazim among horses with disheveled forelocks.'
'And if you emerge for war, our nobles emerge...
Brave leaders, looking askance, with sharp swords.'

This Sufyan: is Ibn al-Abrad al-Kalbi, and he was one of Al-Hajjaj's knights.

Dayr Hizqiyal (Ezekiel's Monastery)
Dayr Hizqiyal. Abu al-Faraj said: Ja'far bin Qudamah told me, saying: Shurayh al-Khuza'i said: I passed by Dayr Hizqiyal. While I was touring it, there was writing on a pillar, so I read it, and it was:
'Many a night, extended by the breath of the lover...
In length, I cut through with sobbing.'
'And bliss, like the union of the one I used to love...
I exchanged for the misery of blame.'
'They attributed madness to me to hide...
What is in my heart of youthfulness and depression.'
'I wish I had what they claimed of losing my mind...
For it is better than the length of this torment.'
And beneath it was written: "I loved so I was forbidden, I was chased and displaced, I was separated from home, veiled from the intimate and the tranquil, imprisoned in this monastery out of injustice and aggression, and shackled in iron for ages:
'And I, despite what has befallen me and afflicted me...
Am possessor of strength, enduring against the calamities.'
'If the days turn, I will win my desire...
And if I remain, my hope is cast away.'
'How many a dead one from worry, rage, and heartbreak...
Is patient for what day and night bring.'
He said: I wrote down what I found and asked about its author. They said: A man loved a cousin of his, so his uncle imprisoned him in this monastery fearing he would be exposed regarding his daughter. His family gathered, came, took him out, and married him to her against the uncle's will.

Dayr Hannah - Al-Ukayrah
Dayr Hannah: In Al-Ukayrah, in the district of Al-Balikh. Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani mentioned Dayr Hannah and said: Abu Nuwas mentioned it in his poetry, meaning in his saying:
'O Dayr Hannah of Dhat al-Ukayrah...
Whoever sobers up from you, I am not sobering.'
'Every shunned one, separated, visits it...
From the nobles, upon it are old sackcloths.'
'Among youths whom their fear did not leave...
The occurrence of what they feared, except as ghosts.'
'They do not approach water with a vessel...
Except scooping from the pools with the palm.'
He said: Al-Ukayrah: A pleasant land with many orchards, gardens, and waters. He said: In Al-Hirah also there is a place called Al-Ukayrah in which there is a monastery. Al-Ukayrah are small domes inhabited by monks. The singular of them is called: Al-Kirah. Bakr bin Kharijah also mentioned this monastery. He said:
'Leave the orchards of myrtle and apples...
And aim for the garden of Dhat al-Ukayrah.'
'To the estates, for the monastery opposite them...
At Al-Ukayrah is from the monastery of Ibn Waddah.'
'Dwellings I never ceased for a time to stick to...
The sticking of one going early to pleasures and returning.'
And in Al-Hirah [Al-Hirah, Iraq] also is a place called Al-Ukayrah, and in it is a monastery built by Abd bin Hanif from Banu Lihyan, who were with Lakhm, and two kings of Al-Hirah were from them. I think it is the one Bakr bin Kharijah meant, because he is Kufan in the poetry recited previously. Regarding these Ukayrah, Ali bin Muhammad al-Alawi, al-Hammani says:
'How many a stop you have at Al-Khawarnaq...
Not equaled by the stops (at Hajj).' 
'Between Al-Ghadir to Al-Sadir...
To the monasteries of the bishops.'
'So the stops of the monks in...
The rags of a female fearful one and a male fearful one.'
'Ruins, as if their gardens...
Are clothed in the flags of embroidered garments.'
'And as if their pools...
In them are tenth-markers in the Qurans.'
'Their beginnings meet their ends...
With the colors of the shelf-cloths.'
'Maritime are its winters...
Land-like in it are the summers.'
'Pearl-like are its pebbles...
Camphor-like from it are the heights.'
'Its rain-clouds spent the night churning...
In its thundering storm clouds.'
'And as if the flash of its lightning...
In the sky are the swords of the fencers.'
'Then they poured down like a...
Weeping woman with four flowing eyes.'
'So as if its blossoms...
Shake in the stormy winds.'
'The forelocks of the servant girls turning...
With them to the forelocks of the servant girls.'
'She defended it from its gloom...
With white, noble, turning (hearts/swords).' 
'The day of despair smells fragrant...
Evil is evident in the day of the opulent.'
'Generous with the free money, stoppers...
In the day of ruin.'
'Oh for the days of youth...
And what they wore of decorations.'
'And their passing with what I knew...
Of the objectionable things and the acquaintances.'
'Days when your mention was in the...
Diwans of youth at the top of the pages.'
'Oh for my days and the days...
Of the women with pure lips.'
'And the planters of the ben-tree branches...
Upon the dunes of the buttocks.'
'And the makers of the full moon...
Between the eyebrows and the sidelocks.'
'Days when they show opposition...
Without the intentions of the opponent.'

'Bliss stopped upon youth...
And you slipped from those positions.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'Leave the orchards of roses and apples...
And turn, may you be guided, to Dayr al-Ukayrah.'
'Turn to a group, whose figures have become thin...
From worship, except for the worn-out ghosts.'
'Repeating bells echoed...
To the Psalms in the evening and morning.'
'So turn your hearing away from a voice you dislike...
For you will not hear in it the voice of a farmer.'
'Except the study of the Gospel from nearby...
The mention of the Messiah with clarity and eloquence.'
'Oh pleasant one, and aged wine is their masterpiece...
With every type of wide bowl.'
'A waist-banded one serves it to you, possessing slimness...
A brother of wool armors over sackcloths.'
Ahmad bin Umar al-Kufi recounted, saying: There was in Kufa a man of literature with weak means who accepted whatever fell into his hand. He would be brought to Dayr Hannah and drink there until he got drunk, then leave to his family, saying: "I admire the crow for its early rising in seeking sustenance." Perhaps he spent the night there, saying:
'Your night was long at Al-Zawiya...
And spending the night there was health.'
'And under your head was a brick...
And your side thrown upon a reed mat.'
'That is better than leaving...
So the sons of the whore judge over you.'
'And you become either a hostage of prisons...
Or a slain man by a water channel.'
He said: And by Allah, he was found days later killed by a water channel! He is the one who said:
'The pleasure of life to me is none other than one...
It is going early to some taverns.'
'For one of obscure mention, safe from his calamities...
Easy to lead among the brisk, well-trained mounts.'
'Until he settles at the monastery of the son of an unbeliever...
From the Christians, selling wine, famous.'
'As if he tied the zunnar over a sand dune...
And turbaned above the darkness of gloom with light.'
Al-Tharwani said about it:
'My day at the temple of Dayr Hannah ceased not...
The best of clouds pouring in it and making it fertile.'
'Armoring himself at times, and at times drawing...
White swords, and at times wearing armor.'
Likewise, Bakr bin Kharijah al-Kufi said about it:
'Has Al-Khawarnaq been watered from a place...
Of elegant gardens, beloved, chic!'
'I stayed at his Dayr Hannah for a time...
In drunkenness in the morning draught and the evening draught.'
'And among us is one wearing a wreath of flowers...
And one with dyed sidelocks with perfume.'
'As if its gardens in beauty and blossoms...
Are clouds gilded with the flash of lightning.'
'As if the dripping of trees in it...
When the darkness gets dark, represents a train of camels.'
'And what do you wish of the pearls of chamomile...
There, and of the rubies of anemones.'

Dayr Hannah in Al-Hirah
Dayr Hannah: In Al-Hirah [Al-Hirah, Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: It is an ancient monastery built by a clan of Tanukh called Banu Sati'. Opposite it is a high minaret like a watchtower, called Al-Qa'im, belonging to Banu Aws bin Amr, then to a branch of them called Banu Mabraq. The youths of Al-Hirah used to frequent it and drink in it. Al-Tharwani meant it by his saying:
'O Dayr Hannah at Al-Qa'im the Cupbearer...
To Al-Khawarnaq from the monastery of Ibn Barraq.'
'Consolation is not (even if I became abstaining...
From my desire in you) of my form and my morals.'
'May it rain for your effaced traces from an effacer, its landmarks...
Are desolate, and your remaining part is like the brocade of a survivor.'
Dayr Hannah: Abu Nuwas mentioned it:
'O Dayr Hannah of Dhat al-Ukayrah...
Whoever sobers up from you, I am not sobering.'
Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani mentioned in the book "Al-Dayarat": Hannah, and that it is different from the one mentioned by Abu Nuwas, and mentioned that Al-Tharwani said about it:
'O Dayr Hannah at Al-Qa'im the Cupbearer...
To Al-Khawarnaq from the monastery of Ibn Barraq.'

Dayr Hanzalah al-Ta'i
Dayr Hanzalah al-Ta'i: In Al-Jazira [Mesopotamia]. Abu al-Faraj said: Hashim bin Muhammad Abu Dulaf al-Khuza'i told me, saying: Al-Riyashi told me: Abu al-Mahallim told me: Dayr Hanzalah in Al-Jazira. It is attributed to a man from Tayy called Hanzalah bin Abi 'Afra bin al-Nu'man bin Hayyah bin Sa'nah bin al-Harith bin al-Huwayrith bin Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Safar bin Hani bin Amr bin al-Ghawth bin Tayy. This Hanzalah is the uncle of Iyas bin Qabisah bin Abi 'Afra who was the King of Al-Hirah. From his clan was Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i the poet. He was one of the poets of the Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic era); he became an ascetic in the Jahiliyyah, converted to Christianity, and built this monastery, so it has been known by him until now. This Hanzalah is the one who said:
'Whatever the doubt of time may be, I...
See the moon of the night setting like the youth.'
'It appears small, then its light grows...
And its form, until when it has leveled.'

'And approached fading, its light and beam...
And it diminishes until it hides and is not seen.'
'Likewise is the increase of the matter, then its decrease...
And its repetition: in its time after it has passed.'
'You greet the people of the abode...
And the abode is a decoration.'
'And you come to the mountains from their high peaks...
Neither does a rich man delay for the surplus of his wealth...
And if he says delay me and take a bribe, it refuses.'
'Nor from a poor man do they delay for his poverty...
So that the complaint to them would benefit him if he complained.'
Ja'far bin Qudamah told me, saying Hammad bin Ishaq told me from his father: Abu Najah told me: I was with Abdullah bin Muhammad al-Amin when he went out to the districts of Al-Jazira. He had many beautiful estates there. We passed by this Dayr Hanzalah, and it was the days of spring. Around it were gardens that make one forget robes of embroidery, and carpets of greenery and flowers. We stayed in it, and he sent to a vintner near the Euphrates, so we drank. Abdullah had a beautiful voice, skilled in singing and music, witty and perfect. He said:
'O Dayr Hanzalah the ransomed...
You have deposited in me fatigue and toil.'
'I drive a skin of wine to you...
And place upon it the moistened leaves.'
'And start with the morning draught before my companions...
And whoever is active for it is the ransomed one.'
'O monastery, may the morning clouds water you...
Clouds loaded with lightning and thunder.'
'Increasing your growing structure in growth...
And clothing the garden in renewed beauty.'
So we drank the morning draught in it for ten days, and Abdullah and the singers with us sang to us. Abdullah has a melody in this poetry from the light Ramal meter, beautiful. Regarding this monastery, the poet says:
'Su'da knocked on your door between the two banks of Bariq...
My soul is the ransom for her phantom as a knocker.'
'O Dayr Hanzalah, the stirrer of passion for me...
Can you cure the love of the lover?'

Dayr Hanzalah al-Lakhmi
Dayr Hanzalah al-Lakhmi: In Al-Hirah. Abu al-Faraj said: Among the monasteries of Banu Alqama in Al-Hirah is the Monastery of Hanzalah bin Abd al-Masih bin Alqama bin Malik bin Rubba bin Namara bin Lakhm bin Adi bin al-Harith bin Murra bin Udad. Found in the front of the monastery written in lead on engraved teak wood: "This holy temple was built, out of love for the guardianship of truth and honesty, by Hanzalah bin Abd al-Masih. May his sanctification be with the endurance of the world, and just as his friends are mentioned with protection, may the mentioning of the sinner Hanzalah be." Some poets say about it:
'In the courtyard of Al-Hirah is Dayr Hanzalah...
Upon it the tails of joy are let down.'
'I revived in it a welcoming night...
And our cup was circulating among the drinking companions.'
'And the wine in it was like a kindled fire...
And all of us were exhausting what was bestowed upon him.'
'In it, the one who blamed him finds pleasure while disobeying...
Hastening before he meets his designated time.'

Dayr al-Khusyan (The Monastery of Eunuchs)
Dayr al-Khusyan: In Ghor al-Balqa between Damascus and Jerusalem. Abu Zayd al-Asadi recounted saying: I entered upon Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik, and he was sitting on a dais paved with red marble, furnished with green brocade, in the middle of a garden with thick trees, whose fruits had ripened. Opposite every side of the dais was a garden that bloomed with spring plants and blossoms. At his head were maidservants, each one more beautiful than her companions, as if they were scattered pearls. In their hands were pitchers with the colors of wines, and bowls of crystal. The drink had taken effect on him. I said: "Peace be upon you, O Commander of the Faithful, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings." Sulayman was looking down, so he raised his head and said: "Abu Zayd, on a day like this, do you greet with the greeting of the living?" I said: "O my master, O Commander of the Faithful, has the Resurrection risen?" He said: "Yes, for the people of passion!" Then he looked down, raised his head, and said: "Abu Zayd, what is good in this day of ours?" I said: "Red coffee (wine) in a white glass, handed to me by a slender, curvaceous, slim, aquiline-nosed, large-eyed girl. I drink it from her palm and wipe my mouth with her mouth." Sulayman looked down for a long time while his tears flowed. When the maidservants saw that from him, they moved away from him. He said: "Abu Zayd, by Allah, you have settled in a day in which is the expiration of your term, the end of your duration, and the annihilation of your life. By Allah, I will strike your neck unless you inform me of what stirred this description from your heart." I said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful. I was sitting at the gate of your brother Sa'id bin Abd al-Malik, and suddenly a girl came out to the courtyard of the palace. She wore a flowing shirt through which the whiteness of her breasts, the roundness of her navel, and the embroidery of her waistband were visible. On her foot were sandals whose whiteness of her feet shone against their redness. She had a single braid hitting her waist, a forelock curled on her forehead, two temples like the letter Nun on her cheeks, eyebrows arched over eye sockets filled with magic, and a nose like a cane of pearl.

And she was saying: 'Servants of Allah, what is the medicine for what is complained of? And what is the treatment for what is not forgotten? The veil has been long, the letter slow, the mind is flying, the intellect is deep, the eye is tearful, insomnia is permanent, passion is present, the soul is bewildered, the heart is snatched, and the heart is detained. May Allah have mercy on a people who lived with endurance and died of grief. If only there were a trick in patience, or a means to consolation.' So I said: 'O girl, are you human or Jinn? Celestial or terrestrial? For the sharpness of your intellect has amazed me, and the beauty of your speech has astounded me.' She covered her face with her palm and said: 'Excuse me, O speaker, for how desolate is passion without help, and suffering blockage with stubbornness.' Then she left. So by Allah - O Commander of the Faithful - I did not eat anything good but choked on it, nor saw anything beautiful but it appeared ugly in my eyes due to her beauty. Sulayman said: 'Ignorance almost provokes me, and infatuation returns to me, and forbearance escapes me. That is Al-Dhalfa, about whom the poet says:
'Al-Dhalfa is but a ruby...
Brought out from the purse of a Dehqan (landlord).'
Her purchase cost my brother a million dirhams. She is in love with a youth who bought her from him. By Allah, no one dies except by regret for her, nor leaves the world except with a lump in the throat for her. In patience is solace, and in expecting death is bewilderment. So conceal - O Abu Zayd - the conversation. O boy: weigh down his hand with a purse of money.' He said: When Sa'id died, she came to Sulayman. There was no one more beautiful in her time. She possessed his heart and prevailed over him to the exclusion of all his other wives and slave girls. He went out one day near the monastery of the monks and pitched his tent in a green garden, elegant with flowers, possessing orchards and joy, surrounded by types of fresh, tender flowers, ranging from bright yellow to pure white to brilliant red. It was like Hadhrami garments and star-patterned cloaks. The wind carried from it the breeze of pungent musk, and its scent diffused the fragrance of crushed ambergris. He had a singer he was intimate with, relied upon, and secluded with often, listening to his talk and singing, called "Sinan." This "Sinan" was the most beautiful of people in face and the wittiest in charm. He ordered him, so he pitched his tent in a green garden, elegant with flowers, possessing orchards and joy, surrounded by types of fresh, tender flowers near him. "Al-Dhalfa" had gone out with Sulayman to that picnic spot. Sulayman remained his day with Sinan in perfect joy and complete happiness until night came. Sulayman left to his tent, and Sinan left to his place. He found a group had camped by him, so they greeted him. He returned their greeting, happy with their arrival, joyful with their staying. He brought them food, and they ate. He presented wine, and they took from it. He said: "Is there any need?" They said: "We only came to you for hospitality." He said: "You have settled in a spacious home, and descended in a fertile side." They said: "As for food, we have eaten; and as for wine, it is present; there remains listening (music)." He said: "As for listening, there is no way to it with the jealousy of the Commander of the Faithful and his prohibition of me from singing, except what is in his assembly." They said to him: "We have no need for food and drink with you unless you let us hear." When he saw they would not be neglected, he raised his voice and sang these verses:
'A veiled woman heard my voice, so it kept her awake...
From the end of the night until wakefulness wearied her.'
'Guards did not block the voice nor a lock...
So her tears flow at the coming of the voice.'
'She lowers over her thighs a yellow-dyed garment...
And the jewelry is visible on her upper chest, a waist.'
'On the night of the full moon, her bedfellow does not know...
Is her face more splendid with him or the moon?'
'If she were released, she would walk towards me on a foot...
That almost splits from delicacy due to walking.'
When "Al-Dhalfa" heard the voice of "Sinan," she went out to the courtyard of the tent to hear the voice. She did not hear anything of beautiful blowing along with what coincided with the time of the moonlit night, except she saw all of that in herself, her time, and her state. That stirred something dormant in her heart, so her eyes overflowed with tears and her sobbing became loud. Sulayman woke up and did not find her in the tent. He went out to its courtyard and saw her in that state. He said to her: "What is this, O Al-Dhalfa?" She said: "O Commander of the Faithful:
'Many a magnificent voice from a deformed one...
Ugly of face, base of father and grandfather.'
'His voice impresses you, and perhaps he is...
Attributed to a slave woman along with a slave.'
Sulayman said: "Leave me from this. By Allah, something from him has mixed in your heart. O boy: bring me 'Sinan'." Al-Dhalfa called a servant of hers and said: "If you beat the messenger to 'Sinan' and warn him, you will have ten thousand dirhams and you are free." But Sulayman's messenger beat him and brought him. When he stood before him, and Sulayman was trembling with jealousy, Sulayman said: "Who are you?" He said: "I am Sinan." He said:
'May his mother be bereaved of Sinan...
He was a basil plant for her to smell.'

'And his maternal uncle and his paternal uncle be bereaved of him...
Possessor of foolishness whose life distresses him.'
Sinan said:
'Keep me until the morning, I will offer an excuse...
Indeed, my tongue is broken by the drink.'
'Your Kalbi knight attacks in a day...
So if he commits a sin or stumbles.'
'Then the forgiving master is more worthy to forgive.'
Then he said: "O Sinan, did I not forbid you from such an act?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, intoxication carried me, and people visited me at night, and I am the slave of the Commander of the Faithful. If he sees fit not to waste his share of me, let him do so." He said: "As for my share of you, I will not waste it, but I will not leave for women a share in you. O Sinan, do you not know that when a man sings, the woman listens to him? And that when the horse neighs, the mare desires him? And that when the male camel rumbles, the female camel submits to him? O boy, bring me a cupper and castrate him." He lived after that for a year and died. So that monastery was named: Dayr al-Khusyan (The Monastery of Eunuchs), and it is known by that until today.
Ahmad bin Abd al-Aziz al-Jawhari told me - and this report is the soundest of what was narrated regarding that in chain of transmission - he said: Abu Zayd Umar bin Shabba told us from Ma'n bin Isa. And Isma'il bin Yunus told us, saying: Umar bin Shabba told me, saying: Abu Ghassan told me: Ibn Janah said: Ma'n bin Isa told me from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Zinad from his father and from Muhammad bin Ma'n al-Ghafari. They said: The reason why the Mukhannathun (effeminates) were castrated in Medina was that Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik was in a club of his chatting at night on a roof. His companions dispersed from him, so he called for ablution water. A slave girl of his came with it. While she was pouring it over him, he signaled with his hand and pointed with it twice or thrice, but she did not pour over him. He disapproved of that and raised his head, and lo, she was listening intently towards the camp. And lo, the voice of a man singing. He listened to him until he heard all that he sang. When it was morning, he gave permission to the people, then brought up the mention of singing and softened regarding it until the people thought he desired and wanted it. They elaborated on it with ease and mentioned who listened to it. Sulayman said: "Is there anyone left who is heard from?" A man from the group said: "I have, O Commander of the Faithful, two men from the people of Ayla, skilled and masterful." He said: "And where is your house?" He pointed to the direction from which the singing was. He said: "Send for them." He did so. The messenger found one of them and brought him to Sulayman. He said: "What is your name?" He said: "Samir." He asked him about singing, and he admitted to it. He said: "When was your last time with it?" He said: "Last night." He said: "And where were you?" He pointed to the direction from which Sulayman heard the singing. He said: "So what did you sing?" He informed him of the poetry Sulayman had heard. He turned to the group and said: "The camel rumbled so the she-camel submitted, the billy goat bleated so the ewe opened up, the pigeon cooed so the female pigeon strutted, and the man sang so the woman was moved." Then he ordered him and he was castrated. He asked about singing, where is its origin? It was said: In Medina among the Mukhannathun, and they are its leaders and the skilled ones in it. So he wrote to Abu Bakr bin Muhammad bin Amr bin Hazm al-Ansari, who was his governor over it, to castrate whoever was there of the singing Mukhannathun. - Musa bin Ja'far bin Abi Kathir claimed, saying: Some scribes told me: I read Sulayman's letter in the Diwan, and I saw on the Kha (of 'Ihsi' - count) a dot like an Ajwa date. He said: And whoever does not know says: The reader misread it, and it was 'Ahsi' (count). He said: So Ibn Hazm tracked them down and castrated nine of them. Among them were: Al-Dallal, Tarif, and Habib Nawmat al-Duha. Some of them said when he was castrated: "The circumciser and the circumcised are safe." This is a phrase a boy says when he is circumcised. He said: Ibn Abi Thabit al-A'raj claimed. He said: Hammad bin Nashit al-Hasani told me. He said: We came from Mecca and with us was Badraqus, who was the one who circumcised them, and his boy had helped him in castrating them. We stayed with Habib Nawmat al-Duha. He celebrated us and honored us. Thabit said to him: "Who are you?" He said: "O son of my brother, do you ignore me when you oversaw my circumcision!" Or he said: "And you circumcised me." He said: "Oh shame! Which of them are you?" He said: "I am Habib." So I avoided his food and feared he would poison me. He said: And Al-Dallal's beard began to fall out after a year or two.
As for Ibn al-Kalbi, he mentioned from Abu Miskin and Laqit that Ayman wrote to count (ihsa') those in Medina of the Mukhannathun to know them, so he could send to him whoever he chose for the delegation. He thought he wanted castration (khisa'), so he castrated them.
Waki' told me, saying: Abu Ayyub al-Madini told me, saying: Muhammad bin Salam told me, saying: Ibn Ja'dubah told me - and I copied from the book of Ahmad bin al-Harith al-Kharraz - from al-Madini from Ibn Ja'dubah, and the wording is his:

That what provoked Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik to do what he did to the Mukhannathun who were in Medina, was that he was lying on his bed at night, and a slave girl of his was by his side. She was wearing a tunic and a cloak, both yellow-dyed, and two sashes of gold, and on her neck were beads of pearl, peridot, and ruby. Sulayman was infatuated with her. In his camp was a man called Samir al-Ayli who sang. Sulayman did not think of his singing due to being occupied with her and attentive to her. She was distracted from him, not answering him, listening intently to the man, until that became long for him. He turned his face away from her in anger, then returned to what he was distracted from understanding by her. He heard Samir singing with the best voice and sweetest tone:
'A veiled woman heard my voice, so it kept her awake...
From the end of the night until wakefulness consumed her.'
'She lowers over her neck the folds of a yellow-dyed garment...
And the jewelry from her is on her upper chest, a waist.'
'On the night of the half (full moon), her bedfellow does not know...
Is her face more splendid with him or the moon?'
And it is narrated: 'Is her face what he sees... or is her face the moon?'
'If she were released, she would walk towards me on a foot...
That almost splits from delicacy due to walking.'
- The song is by Samir al-Ayli, Ramal Mutlaq with the ring finger from Habash... And Dhaka' Wajh al-Ruzza told me that he heard a melody in it by Al-Dallal from the Heavy First meter.
- Sulayman did not doubt that what was with her was from what she heard, and that she loved Samir. So he sent immediately someone to bring him and imprisoned him. He called for a sword and a leather mat (for execution) for her, and said: "By Allah, you will tell me the truth or I will strike your neck!" She said: "Ask me what you want." He said: "Tell me what is between you and this man?" She said: "By Allah, I do not know him nor have I ever seen him. I am a girl raised in Hejaz, and from there I was brought to you. By Allah, I do not know anyone in this land but you." He pitied her and brought the man and questioned him, and was gentle with him in questioning, but did not find any way between him and her. He did not feel right releasing him intact, so he castrated him, and wrote regarding the Mukhannathun with the same order. This narration is authentic.

Dayr Darzijan
Dayr Darzijan: Near Baghdad, on the Tigris, on the western side of it. Abu al-Hasan al-Wasiti al-Sufi said to me: I read on the wall of Dayr Darzijan: So-and-so son of So-and-so al-Dimashqi attended while saying:
'If the distance of separation has parted between us...
My heart is residing with you and staying.'

Dayr al-Rusafa
Dayr al-Rusafa: Ibn Asakir mentioned that its name is "Dayr Hanina," and that the name of the owner of the poem is: Al-Farkh. And that Al-Mutawakkil ordered the demolition of the monastery: Ibn Asakir - Al-Zahiriyah Manuscript - 19 - Folio 145.
Al-Bakri said: It is in Damascus 2 - 580.
- Yakut clarified that this monastery is located in Rusafa Hisham [Ar-Rusafa, Syria], which is eight days from Damascus. Mu'jam al-Buldan (Dayr al-Rusafa).
- It is inferred from Al-Bakri that it is of Roman construction... Royal Romans (Melkites). Al-Bakri.
- Yakut mentioned that he saw the monastery, and decided that it is one of the wonders of the world in beauty and architecture. Mu'jam al-Buldan (Dayr al-Rusafa).
- In this monastery, a poet said, pointing to its glory, and alluding to the Umayyads:
'I see you panicked, O Dayr al-Rusafa...
The morning the Caliphate shifted from you!'
'So do not panic and shed tears in grief...
For every gathering has a blight!'
Dayr al-Rusafa in Rusafa Hisham bin Abd al-Malik. Abu Nuwas passed by this monastery and said about it:
'There is no monastery like the monastery in Rusafa...
In it is what souls desire and love.'
'I spent a night in it and fulfilled desires...
And a day whose two ends I filled with amusement.'
Abu al-Faraj said: Ja'far bin Qudamah told me, saying: Abu Abdullah bin Hamdun told me said: I was with Al-Mutawakkil when he went out to Al-Sham. He rode one day from Damascus recreating in Rusafa Hisham, visiting his palaces and the palaces of his children. Then he went out and entered an old monastery there, of Roman construction, among rivers, farms, and trees. While he was touring it, he saw a patch of paper stuck up. He ordered it to be torn off. It was torn off, and in it was:
'O dwelling by the monastery that has become empty...
The north and west winds play in it.'
'As if white, sociable women did not inhabit you...
And houris did not strut in your courtyard.'
'And sons of kings from Ab Shams, masters...
Their small one is great among mankind.'
'If they wear their armor, they are lions...
And if they wear their crowns, they are full moons.'
'However, on the day of meeting they are lions...
And on the day of giving they are seas.'
'Around you are banners belonging to them and armies...
And horses having snorting after neighing.'
'Nights when Hisham was residing in Al-Rusafa...
And in you was his son, O monastery, while he was a prince.'
'When life was fresh and the Caliphate was supple...
And you were sleek and time was inexperienced.'
'And your garden was trained, and your blossoms shining...
And the life of Banu Marwan in you was fresh.'

'Indeed, may the rain water you with the downpour of a cloud...
Upon you, having an early morning after the evening.'
'I remembered my people while alone and wept for them...
With sorrow, and the likes of me are worthy of weeping.'
'And I consoled my soul, a soul that whenever...
The memory of my people runs to it, has a moan and a sigh.'
'Perhaps a time that was unjust to them one day...
Will turn for it with what souls desire.'
'So a sad one rejoices, and a miserable one becomes blessed...
And a captive is released from the tightness of the bond.'
'Slow down, for today is followed by tomorrow...
And the changes of fortune turn!'
He said: When Al-Mutawakkil read it, he was terrified by it and took it as a bad omen, saying: "I seek refuge in Allah from His bad decrees!" Then he called for the owner of the monastery and said to him: "Who wrote this note?" He swore that he did not know. He said: "Since the Commander of the Faithful descended in this place, I control nothing of the affairs of this monastery. The soldiers and the Shakiriyya enter and exit, and the limit of my ability is that I am hiding in my cell." He intended to strike his neck and destroy the monastery, but his companions spoke to him until his anger subsided. Then it became clear after that that the one who wrote the verses was a man from Banu Ruh bin Zinba' al-Judhami, and his mother was one of the freed slaves of Hisham bin Abd al-Malik.

Dayr al-Ruha (Monastery of Edessa)
Dayr al-Ruha: In Al-Jazira between Mosul and Al-Sham [Sanliurfa, Turkey]. Abu Muhammad Hamza bin al-Qasim al-Shami told me: He said: I passed by the church of Al-Ruha during my journey to Iraq. I entered it to witness what I used to hear about it. While I was in my touring, I saw written in red on one of its corners: So-and-so son of So-and-so attended while saying:
From the advancing of the intelligent one, if ordeal rides him is the interruption of life, and the presence of death. And the severest torment is the prolongation of lives in the shadow of misfortune. And I am the sayer:
'I have an ambition whose lowest station is Suha (a star)...
And a soul that transcended with noble deeds and intellect.'
'I was wealthy in Marw [Merv, Turkmenistan], near...
But the days brought me to the church of Al-Ruha.'
'If I were known in it, I would not stay in it...
But I have become a stranger in it.'
'It is the habit of days to distance the chosen one...
And to separate the gathered, and to disturb the desired.'
So I appreciated the poetry and prose and memorized them.

Dayr Zurara
Dayr Zurara: It is between Kufa and Hammam A'yun, on the right of the pilgrim from Baghdad. It is pleasant, with many taverns and drink, not devoid of those seeking amusement and play, and preferring idleness and revelry. Hashim bin Muhammad al-Khuza'i told me, saying: Al-Abbas bin Maymun bin Ta'i told us, saying Ibn Khurdadhbih told me: Muti' bin Iyas and Yahya bin Ziyad went out performing Hajj. They sent their luggage ahead and one of them said to the other: "Would you like us to go to Zurara and revel for our night at it, then catch up with our luggage?" That remained their habit until the people returned from Mecca. He said: So they rode their camels and shaved their heads and entered with the returning pilgrims. Muti' said about that:
'Did you not see me and Yahya having performed Hajj...
And Hajj was of the best trade.'
'We went out seeking good and righteousness...
But the road inclined us to Zurara.'
'So the people returned having gained and performed Hajj...
And we returned laden with loss.'
This report has been narrated for Bashar bin Burd and others.

Dayr Zakka
Dayr Zakka: It is a monastery in Al-Raqqah [Raqqa, Syria]. Opposite it is a hill called: Tell Zufar, which is Zufar bin al-Harith al-Kilabi. In it is an estate called Al-Salihiyya, laid out by Abd al-Malik bin Salih al-Hashimi - thus said Al-Isfahani - containing an orchard described as beautiful, and two ancient cypress trees. Poets have mentioned it and mentioned its splendor, and longed for it. Al-Hasan bin Ali told me, saying Abd al-Allah bin Abi Sa'd told us saying: Muhammad bin Abd al-Allah bin Malik told me. And Muhammad bin Khalaf bin al-Marzuban told me of it, saying Abu al-Abbas al-Katib told me said: Al-Rashid loved Maridah - his slave girl - and he had left her behind in Al-Raqqah. When he arrived at the City of Peace (Baghdad), he missed her, so he wrote to her:
'Peace be upon the distant stranger...
The greeting of a lover, depressed because of him.'
'A gazelle whose pastures are at Al-Balikh...
To Dayr Zakka to Qasr al-Khashab.'
'O one who helped against himself...
By leaving behind, obediently, the one he loved.'
'I will cover... and covering is of my nature
The love of the one I love with one I do not love.'
When his letter arrived to her, she ordered Abu Hafs al-Shatranji - the companion of Ulayya - so he answered Al-Rashid on her behalf with these verses, saying:
'Your letter came to me, O my master...
And in it are wonders, all wonder.'
'Do you claim that you are a lover of me...
And that you are infatuated and fond of me?'
'If this were so, you would not be...
Leaving me as an opportunity for anguish.'
'While you are in Baghdad grazing in it...
The plants of pleasure with whom you love.'
'O one who shunned me while I did not shun him...
O one who saddened me with what is in the books.'
'Your letter has increased me in yearning...
And kindled my heart with the heat of flame.'

'So grant that, yes, I have concealed the passion...
But how to conceal a flowing tear?'
'And were it not for fearing you, O my master...
The swift she-camels would have brought me to you.'
When Al-Rashid read her letter, he immediately sent a servant on the post-horse to bring her down to Baghdad via the Euphrates, and ordered all the singers, so they sang his poetry.

Dayr Sa'd
Dayr Sa'd in western Mosul near the Tigris, attributed to Sa'id bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. Abu al-Faraj Ali bin al-Husayn al-Isfahani said: Al-Harami bin Abi al-Ala told us, saying Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar told us, saying Muhammad bin al-Dahhak told me from his father, saying: I found in a book in the handwriting of Al-Dahhak saying: Aqil bin 'Ullafah went out with his two sons: 'Ullafah and Jaththama, and his daughter Al-Jarba', until they came to a daughter of his married into Banu Marwan in Al-Sham, who had been widowed. Then they returned with her until they were on some road, Aqil bin 'Ullafah said:
'She fulfilled a wish from Dayr Sa'd and it has been long...
That upon a breadth they butted it with skulls.'
'If you descend a land whose crow dies...
In it of thirst, give them the nose-rings.'
Then he said: "Complete it, O 'Ullafah." 'Ullafah said:
'So they became in the waterless desert carrying youths...
Drunk from the night journey, with tilted turbans.'
'If they leave a flag in a desert...
They measure with arms to another obliterated one.'
Then he said: "Complete it, O Jarba'." She said: "And am I safe?" He said: "Yes." She said:
'As if slumber gave them Sarkhadi wine to drink...
Wine that walks in the back and the legs.'
Aqil said: "You drank it, by the Lord of the Kaaba! Were it not for the safety, I would have struck with the sword under your earring. Could you not find speech other than this!" Jaththama said: "And did she do wrong! She only completed (the verse), and there is no one but me and you." So Aqil shot him with an arrow, hitting his leg, and the arrow pierced his leg and the saddle. Then he attacked Al-Jarba' and hamstrung her she-camel, then loaded her onto Jaththama's she-camel and left him wounded with Al-Jarba's she-camel. Then he said: "Were it not that Banu Murrah would revile me, you would not have tasted life." Then he left heading to his family and said: "If you inform your family about Jaththama, or tell them that anything other than the plague hit him, I will kill you." When they arrived at the people of Abir (who are Banu al-Qayn), Aqil regretted what he did to Jaththama. He said to them: "Would you like a slaughtered camel that broke down?" They said: "Yes." He said: "Then stick to the trace of this mount until you find the slaughtered camel." The people went out until they reached Jaththama and found him drained by blood. They carried him, divided the camel, lodged him with them, and treated him until he healed. They rejoined him with his people. When he was near them, he sang:
'Does our blamer excuse, or does he blame for youth...
While they and the youths are but halves (siblings/partners).' 
The people said to him: "You only just escaped the wound your father inflicted on you earlier, and you have returned to what he hates. Refrain from this and the like; if you meet him, no evil or harm will reach you from him." He said: "It is but a thought that crossed the mind, and the rider sings when he travels."

Umr Safar Yeshu
Umr Safar Yeshu: Below the city of Wasit [Wasit, Iraq]. Abu Abdullah al-Wasiti, the poet known as Ibn al-Ajurri told me, saying: I used to associate with a group of witty people and sons of chiefs, and we would meet over drink constantly. A youth among them invited us to the monastery (Umr) which is below the city of Wasit, known as Umr Safar Yeshu. We went, having with us singing, instruments, and drink, everything elegant. We stayed three days, and pleasant times passed for us there. We departed on the fourth day and dispersed after that for livelihoods and businesses. When months had passed after that, we were invited to the monastery. When we got into the cell where we had drunk that time, the youth said to us: "Shall I not tell you of my state after you?" We said: "Yes." He said: When you departed from us, a young man of good appearance and view came to me, accompanied by a clean-faced boy in similar attire, whom I reckon was a lover of his. He said to me: "Where are the youths who were gathered with you? For they left early in the dark." He became sad, and depression was evident in his face. Then he asked me about your condition, what you did, and how long you stayed. I told him, so he became cheerful, and requested what he and his companion ate. They began drinking and making merry, and stayed in their state for three days, doing the like of your deed. When it was the fourth day, he bade me farewell, took a piece of charcoal, and wrote poetry on the wall of the room, saying: "If they return, show it to them." And he left. We rose to the room, and there it was:
'My brothers, I heard of you...
I intended the monastery out of joy.'
'But I found time had separated you...
And thus is time, possessor of calamities.'
'I asked the priest what they did...
So the priest answered with wonder.'
'So we did the like of your deed...
And drank from the blood of the grape.'
'A daughter of the vine aged for a time...
Since the era of Al-Lat and the idols.'
'And we picked the sweet of fruits...
And ate the ripe dates.'

'And we separated in distress...
All of us calling: Oh my sorrow.'
When we returned to Wasit, we searched for the man, but we did not know any news of him, so we knew he was a stranger who passed through the town.

Dayr Sulayman
Dayr Sulayman in the frontier near Duluk [Duluk, Turkey], overlooking Marj al-Ain. It is the utmost in pleasantness. Ja'far bin Qudamah told me, saying: Ibrahim bin al-Mudabbir, following his calamity and its removal from him, governed the Khazar frontiers. His residence was mostly in Manbij [Manbij, Syria]. He went out in some days of his governorship to the districts of Duluk Ra'ban, and left behind in Manbij a slave girl he had as a concubine, a singer called: Ghadir. Some of his scribes told me that he was with him in Duluk, and he was on a mountain of its mountains containing a monastery known as Dayr Sulayman, one of the most beautiful and pleasant of Allah's lands. He stayed in it and called for light food, so he ate and drank. Then he called for an inkwell and paper and wrote:
'O my two cupbearers in the middle of Dayr Sulayman...
Circulate the cups, and give me a second drink and a third.'
'And single out with the pure of it Abu Ja'far my brother...
And the possessor of my trust among mankind and my sincere friend.'
'And turn with it towards Ibn Salam who...
I have affection for, and return after that to Nu'man.'
'And include with it the drinking companions and friends, for I...
Denied my life after my companions and brothers.'
'And do not leave my soul to die of its illness...
For the memory of a beloved who saddened me and distressed me.'
'I journeyed from him due to avoidance and abandonment...
And he came towards me weeping, so he made me weep.'
'And I parted from him - and Allah will gather our union...
With the anguish of a sad one and the thirst of a burning one.'
'And the night of Ain al-Marj, his phantom visited...
So it stirred longing for me and renewed my sorrows.'
'So I overlooked the top of the monastery looking up...
With glancing eyes and looking at a human.'
'Perhaps I see the houses of Manbij, a sight...
That calms my passion and uncovers my griefs.'
'But my gaze fell short and poured with a tear...
And I would be the ransom for the one who, if he knew, would ransom me.'
'And like it is my longing for him facing me...
And my heart whispered to him in conscience and he whispered to me.'

Dayr Samalu
- Dayr Samalu in Raqqat al-Shammasiya in Baghdad, near Al-Baradan. Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Umar told me: I went out one day, having been afflicted by tightness of chest and divided thought, to the place known as Al-Malikiyya. I passed by Dayr Samalu, on the Fadl River. I sat in a place under the shade of a tree in the courtyard of the house humming some verses. Suddenly, a beardless boy like the rising moon passed by me. I said:
- "O youth, alone in a place like this?" He said: "What is in my heart drove me to ride the risk. So by Allah upon you, will you not inform me if a group of Turks passed you with a singer on a donkey, wearing an orange cloak?" I said: "Yes, they are in that orchard. But tell me, do you want to enter upon them?" He trembled a great tremble, and his color did not cease changing until he calmed a little. I continued to console him and encourage him, and I knew that he loved the singer, and that she had left him and broken her promise to him, and went out with the Turks. When he calmed from his sigh and recovered from his swoon, he said: "Allah has bestowed a favor upon me through you, otherwise what is in my heart would have driven me to enter the orchard and end up in an ugly state." Then he stood and asked me to help him and walk with him until he reached the city. He realized the place of error and panicked severely. So I stood with him and strengthened his spirit, and took him on a path between the orchards so that no one walking on the main road would see him. When we neared the city, he took a rag and wrote on the wall of an orchard we passed:
'Where are those covenants, O treacherous one...
And the tender speech under the minaret?'
'We have known that it was falsehood...
And fabrication, flirtation, and cunning.'
'So strive with all effort, for we have forgotten...
Your love, even with the splitting of the gall bladder.'
I said to him: "As if you knew her in the Mosque?" He said: "Yes, by Allah. I thought the bitch would be faithful. I made her swear under the minaret of the Rusafa Mosque with oaths that mountains could not bear, so she swore she would not contact other than me, nor want other than me. When she knew of my departure to visit the Shrine at the Tuffuf (Karbala), she seized the opportunity of my absence and did what she did. When I arrived, I asked about her and was told her news. I went out on my face until you met me and turned me back. May Allah grant you good reward on my behalf, and take charge of rewarding you." We parted after I knew his house, and he became a friend to me.

Dayr Sim'an (St. Simeon's Monastery)
Dayr Sim'an: This monastery became famous for the death of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz in it, but the difference is severe regarding its location, and in determining the place where the Umayyad Caliph fell ill. It was said he died in "Khanasira," and it was said he died in Khanasira and was buried in Dayr Sim'an.
- The author of "Al-Uyun wa al-Hada'iq" mentioned that he died in Khanasir and was buried in Dayr Sim'an in the land of Ma'arrat (al-Nu'man).
- Al-Mas'udi said: In the mention of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz:

He died at Dayr Sim'an in the works of Homs [Homs, Syria] near the lands of Qinnasrin. His grave is famous in this place to this end, honored, visited by many people from the settled areas and the desert; it was not subjected to exhumation in the past time.
- The authenticity of the grave in Homs was doubted in the days of Saladin al-Ayyubi. When he passed by Aleppo in the year 584 AH, and headed from it intending Ma'arrat al-Nu'man [Ma'arrat al-Nu'man, Syria], he passed by Homs and did not stay in it, which indicates that the grave attributed to the Umayyad Caliph was doubted in those days.
- There are numerous monasteries bearing the name Sim'an, most of them famous in the vicinity of Aleppo, Antioch, Damascus, Homs, and Ma'arra, and for that reason, historians were not successful in identifying Umar's grave in one of them.
- It is inferred from Abu al-Faraj's description that the burial of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz was on Mount Qasioun. Ibn Tulun said during his discussion on the Mu'azzamiya and Aziziyya schools - and the construction of the first was in the year 621 AH and the second in the year 635 AH - he said: North of these two schools is a great enclosure with high walls said to have been Dayr Sim'an. It has a door opening to the east and inside it are several honored graves.
Dayr Sim'an in Damascus
It is in the districts of Damascus [Damascus, Syria], near Al-Ghouta, on a piece of the mountain, overlooking it. Around it are orchards and rivers, and its location is very beautiful. It is one of the large monasteries. Umar bin Abd al-Aziz was buried at it, on its outskirts. His eulogist said:
'I said when they included you in the soil and departed...
May the pillar of justice and religion not be distant.'
'They have hidden in the niche of the grave, laid down...
At Dayr Sim'an, the balance of the scales.'
'He whose concern was not a spring he bursts forth...
Nor the palm trees nor the galloping of draft horses.'
Abu al-Faraj mentioned that the owner of Dayr Sim'an entered upon Umar bin Abd al-Aziz with fruit to gift him during his illness. He accepted it from him and ordered dirhams for him. He refused to take them, but he persisted until he took them, saying: "O Commander of the Faithful! It is but from the fruit of our trees." Umar (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "Even if it is from the fruit of your trees!" Then he said: "O owner of Dayr Sim'an! I am dying from this illness of mine." He became sad and wept. Then Umar said to him: "Sell me the place of my grave from your land for a year; then when the year comes, benefit from it."

Dayr al-Susi
Dayr al-Susi in the districts of Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra, Iraq] on the eastern side. Al-Baladhuri said: It is Dayr Maryam (Monastery of Mary), built by a man from the people of Susa, and he inhabited it along with monks with him, so it was named after him. It is in the districts of Surra Man Ra'a on the western side. Ibn al-Mu'tazz mentioned it in his poetry, saying:
'Distract me with the sound of a flute and lute...
And give me the blood of the daughter of the bunch to drink.'
'I drink the wine while it drinks my mind...
And upon that was the killing of Al-Walid.'
'Many a drunkenness whose appointment I made the morning...
And a cupbearer I urged with increase.'
'O nights at Al-Matira and Al-Karkh...
And Dayr al-Susi, by Allah, return.'
'You were to me samples of Paradise...
But without eternity.'
Ahmad bin Abi Tahir said: I intended Surra Man Ra'a seeking one of its grandees with poetry I praised him with. He accepted me and made my gift generous, and gave me a handsome Roman boy. I traveled intending Baghdad. When I had traveled about a parasang, clouds overtook us, so I turned to Dayr al-Susi to stay in it until the rain lightened. The rain intensified and night came. The monk who was in it said: "You are staying here tonight, and I have good drink, so spend the night reveling then leave early." So I spent the night with him. He brought out for me good drink; I had never seen clearer nor more fragrant. The boy spent the night serving me drink, and the monk was my drinking companion, until I died of drunkenness. When I reached morning, I departed and said:
'May (Allah) water Surra Man Ra'a and its inhabitants...
And a monastery belonging to its Susi, the monk.'
'For I spent a night in his monastery...
And a full moon on a branch was my companion.'
'A gazelle gave me drink until the morning...
Yellow (wine) like melting gold.'
'He gave me wine while awake...
And I slept and he slept by my side.'
'And there were things for me, woe from...
Their sin which my recording angel wrote!'

Dayr Saliba (Monastery of the Cross)
Dayr Saliba: Located in the districts of Damascus opposite Bab al-Faradis. It is also known as Dayr Khalid, because Khalid bin al-Walid, when he descended besieging Damascus, his descent was at it.
- Al-Khalidi said that it is next to Bab al-Faradis, and the proof is the saying of Jarir:
'I said to the riders when the journey became serious with them...
Oh the distance of Yabrin from Bab al-Faradis!'
And he recited regarding it the saying of the other, which is:
'O monastery of Bab al-Faradis, the stirrer for me...
Of sadness with its cells and its trees.'
'If I lived ninety years in you accompanying...
My heart would not fulfill from you some of its desires.'
- This monastery is also known as Dayr al-Sa'ima.
- Ibn Asakir said: Dayr Khalid was outside the Eastern Gate next to Bayt al-Abar, so it was ruined.

- Ibn al-Kalbi said that the monastery was one mile from the East Gate [of Damascus, Syria].
- Among the poets who visited this monastery was Abu al-Fath Muhammad bin Ali, known as Abu al-Liqa. He said that he stayed there for a month and said about it:
It is a paradise nicknamed Dayr Saliba ... Its beauty is created with perfection and goodness.
I came to it to stay for a day, so we remained ... In it for a month, and it was a wondrous matter.
Dayr Saliba is near Damascus [Syria], overlooking the Ghouta [Damascus Countryside, Syria]. Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Umar told me, he said: Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin al-Fadl al-Nahwi informed us, he said: Some of the Banu Hamdun told me from his sheikhs, saying: I was with al-Mutawakkil when he went to al-Sham [Syria]. When we were in Homs [Syria], he said, "I want to tour all the monks' churches, and the place known as al-Faradis when we reach it, for I used to hear about the goodness of this place." I said, "The opinion is what the Commander of the Faithful sees."
Then he settled us in a place between great churches and ancient ruins, to which souls find rest, and he who stays there desires not to depart. When he rested from the fatigue of riding, he summoned me and said: "Do you wish to tour?" I said: "As the Commander of the Faithful commands." So he took my hand, and he did not cease exploring those churches and monasteries, witnessing the wonders of images and luxurious items within them. He saw among the young monks and the daughters of the priests faces like moons upon branches, swaying in those porticos and courtyards. Whenever we passed something of that, he would say to me: "Do you see, woe to you, what we are in? I have never seen the like of this!"
Then we were alone with a monk from the caretakers of the church. Al-Mutawakkil kept asking him about the condition of every girl and boy passing by him, and his name and lineage, while he walked. Suddenly, he glanced at writing on the wall of the church. We approached it and it read:
The homeless, stripped stranger attended while saying:
My gathering was scattered after familiarity ... And my body became miserable after hardship.
I walked from Iraq [Iraq] to this portico ... And I departed from it in Dhu al-Hijjah of the year two hundred and one.
And I say:
My affair has turned to the vilest of matters ... And joy has been exchanged for distress.
Calamities of time have afflicted me ... Competing to tear the veil of the concealed.
O soul, have patience for the accidents of the nights ... For everything humbles itself to the decree.
He said: "Woe to you! How curious is this poor man, and how burning is this groan." While we were in that state, a girl passed by us; my eye had never seen her like. She was wearing a Jubbah (gown) and in her hand was incense which she was burning... Al-Mutawakkil said to her: "Come here, O girl." She approached with good manners and perfection. He said to the monk: "Who is this?" He said: "My daughter." He said: "And what is her name?" He said: "Sa'anin."
Al-Mutawakkil said: "Give me water to drink." She said to him: "O my master, our water here is from the water of the ponds, and I do not deem the monks' vessels clean enough for you. If it were suitable to quench your thirst, I would have been generous with it for you." Then she hurried and came with a silver jug containing water. He signaled to me to drink it, so I drank it. His wonder for her and his desire for her intensified. He said to her: "O Sa'anin! If I loved you, would you make me happy?" She sighed and said: "As for now, I am your slave. But if I knew the truth of your love, and you took hold of your heart, then how I fear the occurrence of tyranny when authority takes hold. Have you not heard the saying of the poet:
You were a slave to me in the beginning of the matter ... Then when you possessed, you became an enemy.
Where is that joy at the time of meeting ... It has become avoidance and distance from me."
Al-Mutawakkil was moved with joy and almost tore his shirt. Then he said to her: "Gift yourself to me today so that you and I may drink, for I am your guest." She said to him: "With welcome and ease." Then she took us up to an upper room overlooking all those churches. We saw a beautiful view. Then she went and brought clean, thin breads. It seemed Al-Mutawakkil refrained from it due to the dignity of the Caliphate, so he asked her permission to bring food, and she permitted it. So a lamb, sanbusaj (samosas), and things easy to take of similar food were brought. She found what was brought to be elegant and was awed by the utensils. She realized Al-Mutawakkil's status, so she stood before him serving him and bowing to him, but he prevented her. Then her father came to us with wine from the communion house; Al-Mutawakkil mentioned that he had never seen its like. He drank and she drank with him. I asked to be excused due to a fever that had afflicted me that night, so he excused me. He was completely delighted with her, her charm, and the sweetness of her logic.
When the wine took hold of her, she said: "Shall I sing to you, O my master, from our singing, despite the weakness of the craft?" He almost wandered in love and said: "If you do, by Allah, your charm is complete." So she stood and brought something they call the "Qithara" (Guitar/Lyre), played it, and began to sing:
O suitor of affection from me, welcome ... Hearing and obeying a command, may I not lack you as a suitor.
I am a slave to your passion, so drink and give me drink ... And turn away with your cup from your friend if he refuses.
By the One who raised the sky, you have possessed me ... And left my heart tormented in your love.

Al-Mutawakkil shouted and said to me: "Woe to you! Are you dead?" I woke up and knew that I had erred in ceasing to accompany him. So I took a Ratl (a large cup) and did not stop drinking until I caught up with him. A day passed for us that was unique among days. Then Al-Mutawakkil made her desire [Islam], so she accepted Islam, and he married her. She remained a favorite with him until he was killed while she was in his house. I saw in some copies that a blackbird and a turtledove were crying out on the tops of trees at the monastery, and Al-Mutawakkil listened to them. When she realized he was listening, Sa'anin recited to him:
As if the blackbird is a monk of a church ... The goodness of the time distracted him from his belt (Zunnar).
He made the orbits of the branches his hermitages ... Mourning in his Gospel and his Psalms.
And as if the turtledove laments his sorrow ... With his groaning, his longing, and his sighing.
A lover whose anxieties split him when the dwellings ... Of his companion and his friend drew near to him.
This pleased him from her, and he increased in joy with her and love for her.

**Dayr Abd al-Masih (Monastery of Abd al-Masih)**
Dayr Abd al-Masih: It was built by Abd al-Masih bin Amr bin Baqila al-Ghassani in al-Hirah [near Najaf, Iraq]. Al-Isbahani mentioned it and said: Abd al-Masih was one of the long-lived ones; it is said he lived three hundred and fifty years. This monastery is on the outskirts of al-Hirah [Iraq] in a place called al-Jar'ah. Abd al-Masih is the one who met Khalid bin al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, when he invaded al-Hirah and fought the Persians. They threw at them from their three fortresses, the fortresses of the family of Baqila, with round pottery. He used to go out in front of the horses, so they would shy away from him. Dirar bin al-Azwar said to him: "This is from their plot." So Khalid sent a man to summon a wise man from among them. Abd al-Masih bin Amr came to him, and what happened between them is well-known and famous. He said: Abd al-Masih remained in that monastery after he made peace with the Muslims for one hundred thousand, until he died. The monastery fell into ruin after a period, and an arched structure of stone appeared in it. They thought it was a treasure, but lo, inside was a marble bed with a dead man upon it. At his head was a tablet on which was written:
I am Abd al-Masih bin Amr bin Baqila:
I milked time for its halves during my life ... And I attained wishes beyond increase.
I struggled with affairs and they struggled with me ... Yet I did not submit to a difficult dilemma.
I almost attained the Pleiades in honor ... But there is no path to immortality.

**Dayr Adas**
Dayr Adas in al-Sham [Syria/Levant]. Abu Bakr Muhammad bin al-Hasan bin Durayd told us, he said: Al-Makki informed us from Ibn Abi Khalid, from al-Haytham, he said: Usama bin Zayd informed us, from Zayd bin Aslam, from his father, from Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said:
I went out with some people from Quraysh for trade to al-Sham [Syria] in the Pre-Islamic period (Jahiliyyah). While I was in one of its markets, a patrician seized me by my neck. I went to dispute with him, but it was said to me: "Do not do it, for you will not get justice from him." He took me into a church where there was a great pile of dirt. He brought me a basket and a shovel and said to me: "Move what is here." I sat pondering my affair, how to act. When it was midday, he came to me wearing a Sabaniyah (cloth) through which I could see the rest of his body. He said: "You have, as I see, moved nothing!" Then he gathered his hands and struck my brain with them. I said: "Oh, bereft of your mother, O Umar, have you reached what I see!" Then I jumped to the shovel and struck his head with it, then I buried him in the dirt. I went out aimlessly, not knowing where I was going. I walked for the rest of my day and night, and the next day until midday. I ended up at a monastery and sought shade in its courtyard. A man came out to me and said: "O servant of Allah, what makes you sit here?" I said: "I have lost my companions." He said: "You are not on a road, and you look with the eye of a fearful person. Enter, have some food, and rest." So I entered, and he brought me food and drink and was kind to me. Then he looked me up and down and said: "The People of the Book—or the Books—know that there is no one on earth more knowledgeable about the Book—or the Books—than me, and I find your description to be the description of the one who will drive us out of this monastery and conquer us over it." I said: "O man, you have gone to a wrong interpretation." He said to me: "What is your name?" I said: "Umar bin al-Khattab." He said: "You are, by Allah, our man. So write for me a guarantee for this monastery of mine and what is in it." I said to him: "O man, you have done me a favor, so do not spoil it." He said: "It is only a writing on parchment. If you are our man, then so be it; and if not, nothing will harm you." So I wrote for him concerning his monastery and what was in it. He brought me clothes and dirhams and gave them to me. Then he saddled a female donkey and said to me: "Do you see it?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Ride it, for you will not pass by any people but that they will water it, feed it, and host you. When you reach your place of safety, turn its face back, and they will do the same with it until it returns to me." He said: So I rode it until I caught up with my companions and went with them.

When Umar arrived in al-Sham [Syria] during his Caliphate, that monk came to him with the document; he was the owner of Dayr Adas. When he saw him, he recognized him and then said: "That which Umar has no way out of has come." Then he turned to his companions and told them his story. When he finished it, he turned to the monk and said: "If you host the Muslims, treat their sick, and guide them, we will do that [honor the agreement]." He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful." So Umar fulfilled it for him.

**Dayr al-Adhara (Monastery of the Virgins)**
Dayr al-Adhara: For the nuns in the Arab East, there are numerous monasteries; we indicated some of them in the introduction.
- Al-Shabushti noted the monastery located in Qati'at al-Nasara (The Christians' Ward) in Baghdad [Iraq] during his era, saying: "And in Baghdad also is a monastery known as 'Dayr al-Adhara' in Qati'at al-Nasara on Nahr al-Dajaj (Chicken River). It was named that because they have a fast of three days before the Great Fast (Lent), called the Fast of the Virgins. When the fast ends, they gather at this monastery to worship and draw near [to Allah]. It is a beautiful monastery."
- Al-Khalidi said: I saw it, and it had virgin women and wine taverns, but the Tigris [River] swept over it with its floods and destroyed it until no trace of it remained. It was mentioned that he passed by it in the year 320 AH while it was populated.
- Dayr al-Adhara: It was a monastery for Syriac nuns in Baghdad [Iraq], in Qati'at al-Nasara, where the Church of Mar Toma (Saint Thomas) for the Syriacs was located. Ibn al-Ibri mentioned it in the events of the year 1002 of the Greeks [approx. 691 AD], and he called it the Monastery of the Sisters. He said that a group of commoners tried to loot it, then they turned away fleeing because news reached them that a crowd of the mob perished in a fire that broke out in the mentioned church due to their actions.
