**Dayr al-Adhara**
Abu al-Faraj al-Isbahani said: It is between the land of Mosul [Iraq] and the land of Bajarma in the works of al-Raqqa [Syria]. It is a great ancient monastery. In it are virgin women who became nuns and stayed there for worship, so it was named after them. It had reached one of the kings that there were women of beauty in it, so he ordered them to be brought to him to choose from them whom he wanted with his own eye. That news reached them, so they stood their night praying and asking [Allah] to suffice them against his evil. A night visitor [death/calamity] struck that king and destroyed him that very night. So they became fasting, and for that reason, the Christians fast the fast known as the Fast of the Virgins until now.
Dayr al-Adhara in Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq] exists until now, inhabited by nuns. The poets have mentioned this monastery frequently. Among them is Abu al-Hasan Jahza al-Barmaki. Abu al-Faraj al-Husayn bin Ali al-Isbahani recited to me what he [Jahza] said about it:
Is there a way to Dayr al-Adhara and a look ... At the goodness before death?
And do I have a drunkenness in the market of al-Qadisiyah ... That comforts my soul while the breeze is gentle?
And do I have a stance at the taverns of al-Matirah ... Watching the exit of the wineskin while it is carried?
To young men whose gathering was not scattered by blame ... Their slogan at the morning is wine.
The bell has spoken after its silence ... And a priest hastened and a wick shined.
He wants to stand for the station by his claim ... And addiction makes him tremble so he leans.
He sings while the causes of correctness support him ... And he has no equal in what he says:
"Is there a way to smell the lavender and a look ... At Qarqara before death?"
And he sang a second time while touching his cup ... And his tears were flowing on his cheeks:
"He will turn away from mentioning me and forget my affection ... And a friend will create a friend after me."
May Allah water a life in which there was no attachment ... For them, and no blamer denied it.
By your life, I did not bear patience for his loss ... And all patience for other than him is beautiful.
He said: When Ubayd Allah bin Abdullah bin Tahir went out from Baghdad [Iraq] to Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq], and Al-Mu'tazz had summoned him, he stayed at this monastery. He stayed there for two days, found it pleasant, and drank there. Then he said these verses:
Do you not see the goodness of our time, O Sa'id ... A laughing time and an arranged garden.
And gardens as if they are cloaks ... Every day they have a new dye.
As if the anemone in it is a lover ... And as if the ox-eye daisy is a lovestruck admirer.
As if the branches leaning are figures ... And as if the blossoms in them are necklaces.
As if the fruits and the green leaves ... Are clothes under which are breasts.
So give it to me as wine that relieves from worry ... And shows our joy and repeats it.
And urge the cup, O Sa'id, for indeed ... A flute has urged you for it and a lute has moved.
And deflower the virginity of pleasures in Dayr ... Al-Adhara, for its like will not return!
Ibn Qudamah mentioned and said:

I attended the funeral of Shaji. When we departed, I entered with Ubayd Allah, assisting him and comforting him. He was looking down, and his tears were flowing on his cheeks. I had never seen a weeper more beautiful than him. Then he raised his head and turned to us, saying:
I swear that if I were afflicted by losing her ... While within me a vein pulsed for life and for relapse,
I would have killed myself upon parting with her ... But she died while my soul had already gone.
He said: Then I attended with him to visit her grave. When he intended to leave, he said:
Whoever visits the home of loved ones for their life ... And for what he hopes of meeting, is capable.
So let him come to the home of loved ones who inhabited decay ... Out of generosity and preservation, and the meeting is the Gathering [Day of Judgment].
He said: And a son of Ubayd Allah from Shaji died, so he visited his grave, then recited:
O gathering place of loved ones after separation ... I see you near, yet the meeting is far.
O wonder, I visit you compelled ... And in you are those I love, yet I turn away from you willingly.
Jahza said: I entered upon Ubayd Allah bin Abdullah bin Tahir one day. Some sheikhs came to him, and he ordered them to sit on his right. Then middle-aged men came, and he ordered them to sit on his left. Then young men entered and stood before him, and he did not order them to sit. I asked him about them, and he said: "These are my sons," and he pointed to the sheikhs, "and these are their sons," and he pointed to the middle-aged men, "and these are their sons," and he pointed to the young men. I said: "Are your sons from one mother or from different mothers?" He said: "All of them are from Shaji." And he recited:
Shaji and I planted in my youth ... The seedlings of passion, so they matured with sweet fruit.
The sons of Shaji grew gray for my back and matured ... And their sons grew gray while she is the owner of my heart.
He said: She has been with me for seventy years. An astrologer had judged that he would die before her, but she died before him. He said:
O wonder of me and of whom I tended ... With the strongest causes of passion, and she tended me.
I was hoping to be her ransom ... But when the time of death came, she ransomed me.

**Dayr Alqama (Monastery of Alqama)**
Dayr Alqama in al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia]: And in al-Jazira is Dayr Alqama. It was built by Alqama bin Adi bin al-Rumayk bin Thawb bin Usus bin Ruba bin Namara bin Lakhm. Adi bin Zayd al-Ibadi says about him, eulogizing him:
Good morning, Alqama bin Adi ... Did you stay today or do you depart?
The young men have departed with their caravan ... And the meat in the lowlands has not been pulled up.
Adi also says about this monastery, and it contains singing:
I drank with the sons of Alqama in the monastery ... I gave them chilled wine when,
It was as if the scent of musk was in its cup ... When we mixed it with the water of the sky.
Whoever is pleased by life and its pleasures ... Let him make wine a ladder for himself.
Alqama, what is the matter with you that you did not come to us ... Did you not desire today to be blessed?
This monastery was a promenade for the princes of al-Hirah [Iraq]: they would eat near it and drink.

**Dayr Futrus and Dayr Bulus (Monastery of Peter and Paul)**
Dayr Futrus and Dayr Bulus: Outside Damascus [Syria]. Abu al-Faraj said: These two monasteries are outside Damascus in the areas of Banu Hanifa in the district of al-Ghouta [Damascus Countryside, Syria]. The place is beautiful, wondrous, with many orchards, trees, and waters. Jarir said:
When I remembered at the two monasteries, I was kept awake ... By the sound of chickens and the striking of bells.
So I said to the riders when the departure became serious for us ... O how far is Yabrin from the Gate of al-Faradis!
He also says regarding it, eulogizing his son:
Sawadah perished, showing my eye flesh ... A hawk screeching atop the high watchtower.
If you have no weeping woman at the two monasteries ... Then many a weeping woman is wailing in the sands.
They said: Your share is reward, so I said to them: ... How can there be stability when I have parted from my lion cubs?

**Dayr al-Qa'im al-Aqsa (The Farthest Standing Monastery)**
Dayr al-Qa'im al-Aqsa is on the bank of the Euphrates [River] on the western side on the road to al-Raqqa [Syria] from Baghdad [Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: I have seen it. It was called al-Qa'im (The Standing) only because it has a high watchtower that was between the Romans and the Persians, used to watch over the edge of the border between the two kingdoms, similar to the hill of Aqarquf in Baghdad [Iraq], and the finger of Khaffan behind Kufa [Iraq]. Near it is a monastery that is now a ruin. I entered it and there was no one in it, nor did it have a roof or a door.
Hashim bin Muhammad al-Khuza'i informed me, he said my uncle Abdullah bin Malik informed me, from his father, he said: Ishaq al-Mawsili said: We went out with al-Rashid to al-Raqqa [Syria]. We passed by al-Qa'im al-Aqsa. Al-Rashid admired the place. The time was spring, and those meadows were filled with anemones and varieties of flowers. So he drank upon that for three days. I entered the monastery and toured it. Lo, there was a female monastery dweller whose breasts were just budding, wearing sackcloth. I had never seen a face more beautiful than hers, nor a figure, nor symmetry. It was as if that sackcloth on her was jewelry. I called for date wine (Nabidh) and drank cups to her face, and I said about her:
At Dayr al-Qa'im al-Aqsa ... Is a gazelle, a fawn with dark lips.
My love for him has worn out my body ... And he does not know what I encounter.

And I hide his love with my effort ... But by Allah, it is not hidden.
Then I called for the lute and sang a beautiful song with it. I kept repeating it and drinking to it, looking at her face, until I became intoxicated. When it was the next day, I entered upon al-Rashid while I was dead drunk. He asked me for news, so I told him my story. He said: "Goodness, by my life!" He called for drink and drank for the rest of his day. When it was evening, he said: "Stand up so that I may disguise myself and enter with you to your female companion, so I may see her."
He rode a donkey and veiled himself with his cloak. We entered, and he saw her and said: "Beautiful, by Allah! You have not wasted what you did." He ordered a cup to be brought, and my lute was brought. I sang the song for him three times. He drank three Ratls (large cups) and ordered ten thousand dirhams for me. I said to him: "O my master, what about the subject of the story?" So he ordered the like of that for her. He ordered that no land tax (Kharaj) be taken from the farms of this monastery, and he granted it to them as a fiefdom. He set upon it a tax of ten dinars every year, to be paid on its behalf in Baghdad [Iraq]. Then we departed.
Muhammad bin Mazid informed me, he said: Hammad told us from his father, he said: We went out with al-Rashid intending for al-Raqqa [Syria]. When we were at the place called al-Qa'im, we stopped. He went out to hunt, and we went out with him. He went far in pursuit of game. A monastery appeared to me, so I headed for it, as I was tired. I looked down upon its owner, and he said: "Do you wish to stay with us today?" I said: "Yes, by Allah, and I am in need of that!" So I dismounted, and he opened the door for me and sat talking to me. He was a very old man who had lived during the the state of Banu Umayyah. He began telling me about the people who had stayed with him, their clients, and their armies. He offered me food, and I accepted. He presented me with food from the food of the monasteries, clean and good. I ate from it. He brought me drink and fresh basil, so I drank from it. He assigned a nun girl to serve me; I had never seen a better face than hers nor more shapely. I drank until I became intoxicated, slept, and woke up at nightfall. I said regarding that:
At Dayr al-Qa'im al-Aqsa ... Is a gazelle, a fawn with dark lips.
My love for him has worn out my body ... And he does not know what I encounter.
And I conceal his love with my effort ... But by Allah, it is not hidden.
I rode and caught up with the army. Al-Rashid had sat for drinking and asked for me but I was not found. I was informed of that. I sang those verses and entered upon him. He said: "Where were you? Woe to you!" I told him the news and sang the song for him. He was delighted and drank to it until he became intoxicated. He delayed the departure the next day, and we went to the monastery and he entered it. He saw the sheikh and made him speak, and he saw the girl who was serving me yesterday. He called for light food and ate from it, and called for drink. He ordered the girl who was serving me yesterday to take charge of serving him and giving him drink, so she did. He drank until his soul was pleased. Then he ordered one thousand dinars for the monastery and ordered the bearing of its land tax for him for seven years. Then we departed.
Hammad said: My father told me, he said: When we were at Tell Azaz in Dabiq [Syria], I went out with friends of mine to picnic in one of its villages. We stayed there for days. Al-Rashid sought me but did not find me. When I heard, I came to al-Fadl bin al-Rabi', and he said to me: "Where were you? The Commander of the Faithful sought you." I told him of our picnic, and he got angry. I feared al-Rashid more than what I encountered from al-Fadl. So I said:
Indeed my heart is at the Tell, Tell Azaz ... With a gazelle from the gazelles of al-Jawazi.
A fawn living in al-Sham [Syria] and in him ... With the charm of Iraq [Iraq] is the form of al-Hijaz [Saudi Arabia].
O my people, for the daughter of a priest who struck ... From you the purity of passion and does not reward.
I swore by the Messiah that she would fulfill the promise ... But she does not intend fulfillment.
I sang it, then I entered upon al-Rashid while he was angry. He said: "Where were you? I sought you but did not find you." I apologized to him and recited this poetry to him and sang it to him. He smiled and said: "An excuse, by your father, and what an excuse!" He did not cease drinking to it and asking me to repeat it all night long until we departed at the rising of dawn. When I arrived at my saddlebag, lo, the messenger of the Commander of the Faithful came to us inviting us. I arrived and entered, and lo, Ibn Jami' was rolling on a bench in the house, intoxicated and restless. He said to me: "O Ibn al-Mawsili, do you know what brought us?" I said: "No, by Allah, I do not know." He said: "But by Allah, I know, a correct knowledge. Your fornicating Christianity brought us, upon you and upon it be the curse of Allah!" The permission came out, so we were permitted in. We entered. When I saw al-Rashid, I smiled. He said to me: "What makes you laugh?" I told him what Ibn Jami' said. He said: "He spoke the truth. It was only that I missed you both and longed for what we were in, so bring us back." So we returned to it until our session ended and we departed.

**Dayr Qurrah (Monastery of Qurrah)**
Dayr Qurrah: It is located opposite Dayr al-Jamajim. Al-Isbahani said: Qurrah, which was built by a man from Lakhm, built it in the days of the reign of Al-Mundhir bin Ma' al-Sama. It is adjacent to Taff al-Barr and Dayr al-Jamajim, on the side of Kufa [Iraq].

Ibn al-Ash'ath had chosen Dayr al-Jamajim so that supplies and provisions would come to him, just as he had resolved to cut off the flow of water from al-Hajjaj and his companions, to kill them with thirst. So al-Hajjaj, out of necessity, camped with his armies at Dayr Qurrah. He said: "What is the name of this monastery?" It was said: "Dayr Qurrah (Monastery of Comfort/Settlement)." He said: "We have possessed the lands and settled in them." He said: "What is the name of the one where Ibn al-Ash'ath camped?" It was said: "Dayr al-Jamajim (Monastery of Skulls)." He said: "The skulls of his companions will increase at it, if Allah wills."

**Qallayat al-Qass (The Priest's Cell)**
Qallayat al-Qass: It is in al-Hirah [near Najaf, Iraq], in a beautiful location. The priest to whom it is attributed was one of the handsome Christians, and he was an ascetic, then became a profligate. Abu al-Faraj mentioned it, and al-Tharwani said regarding it:
O my two friends from Taym and Ijl, may you be guided ... Add with the urging of the cup my today to my yesterday.
If you two greet me with a greeting ... Then do not skip the basil of Qallayat al-Qass.
And with the Azad lily and the roses, throw ... Your narcissus in the East or the setting of the sun.
If you greet me with it, then seclude yourselves ... Praiseworthy, without me, with perfume and saffron.
And if you say: There is no escape from a circulating drink ... And you do not excuse me in delay or confinement,
Then from a Hirah wine, monastic ... Aged for five or increasing over five.
It drags its Izar (garment) over the striking of the mix ... And struts from it in the dyed clothes of the wedding.

**Dayr Ka'b (Monastery of Ka'b)**
Dayr Ka'b in al-Sham [Syria]. Al-Hasan bin Ali informed me, he said: Harun bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik told us, he said: Abu Ayyub al-Madini told me, he said: Ahmad bin Ibrahim the scribe told me, he said: My father told me from a man from the people of al-Sham [Syria], he said:
I was one day staying at Dayr Ka'b, having arrived from a journey. Suddenly, I saw a man who had stopped at the monastery, with luggage, equipment, and a travel bag. He was close to my place. He called for food and ate. He called the monk and gave him two dinars. It appeared there was friendship between them. He brought out wine for him, so he sat drinking and talking to the monk while I was watching them. Then [another man] entered the monastery and sat with them, interrupting their conversation and being heavy in his sitting. He was dull in conversation and stayed long. Some of the servants of the man staying there came to me, and I asked about him. He said: "This is Muti' bin Iyas." When the man stood up and left, Muti' wrote something on the wall and began to drink until he became drunk. When it was the next day, he departed. I came to his place, and written there was:
A rapture—how I was enraptured in Dayr Ka'b ... I almost died from my rapture in it.
I remembered my brothers and drinking companions ... So the memory of my friends stirred weeping.
When they were absent, scattered, and I became alone ... And they distanced between the east of the land and the west.
They are who they are, so it suffices me; I do not seek ... A replacement for them, by your life, it suffices me.
Talha the Good is among them, and Abu al-Mundhir ... Is my friend, and Malik, that is my peer.
O heavy intruder upon us ... When the conversation was good for me and my friends,
Lighten up from us, for you are heavier, by Allah ... Upon us than the parasangs (leagues) of Dayr Ka'b.
Among people are those who are light, and among them ... Is like the millstone of seeds mounted upon my heart.

**Dayr Lubba (Monastery of Lubba)**
Dayr Lubba is on the side of the Euphrates [River]. On the eastern side of it. Abu al-Faraj mentioned it and said: It is also narrated as Lubni with a Nun. He said: It is an ancient monastery on the side of the Euphrates on its eastern bank. It is one of the dwellings of Banu Taghlib in al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia]. Al-Akhtal mentioned it and said:
Dayr Lubba has been effaced of Umayma, and so has al-Hadar ... It has become desolate, except when a traveler visits it.
They finished a concern at the two monasteries they sought ... So they are towards amusement, and their neighbors look askance.
There were battles there between Banu Taghlib and Banu Shayban and struggles over those lands. Ibn Muqbil said:
As if the horses when they came upon Kalb in the morning ... See behind them what they seek.
They were angry, so they do not see retaliation for them ... So let them not pull back until they go out in the morning.
If the eyebrows of the family of Qays were lined with kohl ... With Taghlib after Kalb, we would not have been hospitable.
So the horses of Qays are not safe for you ... And do not hope for the daughters nor the sons.
They raised a dust cloud in Dayr Lubba ... And at the two Hadars they turned the hair gray.
Al-Ra'i said:
They left on the sides of Lubba ... Their women for us when they met us.

**Dayr al-Lujj (Monastery of the Depth/Abyss)**
Dayr al-Lujj: In al-Hirah [near Najaf, Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: It was built by Abu Qabus al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir during his reign. There was no building among the monasteries of al-Hirah better than it, nor a place more pleasant. The poet says about it:
May Allah water Dayr al-Lujj with rain, for it ... Despite its distance, is a monastery beloved to me.
Close to my heart, distant in its place ... And how many are distant in abode yet are close.
A gazelle inhabiting it stirs its memory ... Nasal-voiced, with enchanting eyes, raised [in luxury].
When he recites the Gospel and sways, bending ... A sad, strange heart remembers.
And upon the echoing of his voice, anxieties ... Of sicknesses and palpitations stirred in my heart.
Al-Nu'man used to ride to it every Sunday and every festival, and with him were his family specifically from the family of al-Mundhir, and those who drank with him from the people of his religion. Upon them were gilded brocade suits, and on their heads were gold crowns, and in their waists were belts (Zunnar) set with jewels. Before them were flags topped with crosses. When they finished their prayer, they departed to a lookout on the Najaf [Iraq], and al-Nu'man and his companions drank there for the rest of his day. He would give robes, bestow gifts, carry burdens [pay debts], and give connection. That was the best and most beautiful sight. Regarding Dayr al-Lujj, Ismail bin Ammar al-Asadi says:
I do not forget Sa'da and al-Zarqa on the day they were ... At al-Lujj, east of it, upon the benches.
Singing to us like the blowing of magic, we deposit it ... From us into hearts that became obedient to Ibn Ramin.
We are given to drink a wine like the color of fire, aged ... The sober ones become like madmen from it.
If we mentioned a prayer after it had passed ... We stood for it with neither reason nor religion.
We walk to it slowly, with no movement in us ... As if our legs are being pulled from mud.
We walk with our legs crooked in their placement ... The walk of the geese coming from China.
Or the walk of the blind of a monastery who have no guide ... Except sticks, to Dayr al-Sa'anin.
I love Rubayha, indeed Allah has favored her ... With her beauty and singing of various arts.
So whoever says to her, "Sing," she makes him happy ... [Singing] "You killed me on the day of Dayr al-Lujj, so revive me."

**Dayr Marah Maryam (Monastery of Saint Mary) in al-Hirah**
Dayr Marah Maryam: In the outskirts of al-Hirah [Iraq], overlooking the Najaf [Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: This is an ancient monastery, built by the family of al-Mundhir. It is a beautiful place, between al-Khawarnaq and al-Sadir, and between the Palace of Abu al-Khasib, overlooking the Najaf. In it was a priest called Yahya, a vintner, and he had a son called Yusha (Joshua), whom the witty young men befriended. They would drink at his place to the reading of the Christians and the striking of bells. Bakr bin Kharijah says about him:
We spent the night at Marah Maryam ... May Marah Maryam be watered [with rain].
And for our priest Yahya the dominance ... After the sleep of the sleepers.
And for Yusha and his red ... Wine like dragon's blood.
And for young men who surrounded him ... Disobeying the blame of the blamers.
A gazelle, nasal-voiced, gives them drink ... Delicate in the creation of the wrist.
Shooting hearts with his eyes ... Like the shooting of arrows.
Al-Tharwani defined it, saying:
At Marah Maryam the Great ... And the shade of its courtyard, so stand.
At the Palace of Abu al-Khasib the overlooking ... The looming over the Najaf.
So the sides of al-Khawarnaq and al-Sadir ... The playgrounds of the predecessors.
To the spathed palm trees ... And the doves cooing above them.
So leave the saying of the blamer and ... Come early to the reddish wine with kindness.
And from the poetry of al-Tharwani about it:
Let the days do what they wanted ... If they were generous with a drinking companion and a cup!
And Marat Maryam, and the courtyard in it ... Two gardens of roses and myrtle.
And a gazelle in the glances of his eyes ... Drowsiness in languor, not sleepiness.
And a friend who does not turn away from youthful passion ... Remembering affection, not forgetting.
And embracing an eloquent tambourine ... Singing to me with the poetry of Abu Nuwas:
"And pleasures are nothing but that you see me ... Prostrate between a jug and my cup."
And Bakr bin Kharijah says about it:
At Marah Maryam and at Dayr Zakka ... And Mar Toma and Dayr al-Jathaliq (Monastery of the Catholicos).
And by the Gospel recited by sheikhs ... From the priests in the Ancient House.
And by the Communion and the Crosses, unless ... You have mercy on my sick, yearning heart.
Grant me refuge, I died before you from worries ... And guide me to the face of the road.
For the faces of my affair have narrowed upon me ... And you are the one sought for refuge from the strait.
Abu al-Faraj said: He says this poetry about a boy of a Christian man from the people of al-Hirah [Iraq], called Ashir bin al-Bara al-Sarraf. He has much poetry about him, mentioning the festivals of the Christians and their churches. Di'bil used to admire his saying:
His belt is knotted at his waist ... As if it were cut from my liver.
And he says: I wish these two were mine for a hundred verses of my poetry!
Jaafar bin Qudamah informed me, he said: Maymun bin Harun told me, he said Ishaq al-Mawsili told me, he said: When I went out with Al-Wathiq to al-Najaf [Iraq], we toured al-Hirah and passed by its monasteries. I saw Dayr Maryam in al-Hirah, and I admired its location and the beauty of its building. I said:

Its memory stirs like a gazelle that comes … I sing of the dawn of the two eyes, the foster child, when the Gospel is returned and the table shakes … The heart of the stranger remembered it in sorrow, and my heart stirred at the echo of its voice … Nightingales of ailments and distress. Al-Numan used to ride there every Sunday, and on every festival, accompanied by his household, especially the family of Al-Mundhir, and those of his faith who joined him, wearing gold-embroidered silks, crowns of gold on their heads, belts inlaid with gems, and banners topped with crosses before them. After completing their prayers, they would proceed to a lookout in Najaf, where Al-Numan and his companions spent the rest of the day, giving gifts and offerings, traveling and connecting. It was the most beautiful and finest sight. In the monastery of Al-Luj, Isma'il ibn Ammar Al-Asadi says: I will not forget Sa'dah and Al-Zarqa on the day they were … in Al-Luj, east of the shops, singing like a spell, we gave them … hearts that became tender to Ibn Ramin, watered with drinks like the color of refined fire … those awake became like madmen when we mentioned a prayer after neglect … we went to it without reason or faith, walking slowly as if our feet were lifted from clay … walking like crooked legs of geese from China or blind monks with no guide but sticks … to the monastery of Al-Sa’aneen. I love Rubiha, for Allah favored her … with her beauty and melodious voice. Whoever tells her to sing brings her joy: 'You killed me on the day of Al-Luj, bring me to life.' Monastery of Mary in Al-Hirah: near Al-Hirah, overlooking Najaf. Abu Al-Faraj said: It is an old monastery, built by the family of Al-Mundhir, well-placed between Al-Khurnuq and Al-Sadir, and near Qasr Abi Al-Khasib, overlooking Najaf. There was a priest called Yahya Khimara, with a son called Joshua, loved by the young men, who would drink there according to Christian readings, and ring the bells. Bakr ibn Khurajah said: We spent nights at Mary’s Monastery … giving water to Mary and to the priest Yahya Al-Muhayyam … after sleep, and to Joshua and Khimara … with young men who gathered around … drinking from a fine gazelle … gentle of character, throwing arrows with precision … like the arrows shot. Al-Thurwani said: At the Great Monastery of Mary … near Qasr Abi Al-Khasib … Over Najaf, around Al-Khurnuq … Monastery playgrounds extending to the enclosed palm groves … and doves above, calling. Let the blame fall aside … The red in its delicacy … and from Al-Thurwani’s poetry: Let the days do what they wish … when generosity flows with wine! And Mary’s Monastery and its courtyard … two gardens with roses and myrtle, and a gazelle in his eyelids … drowsy without sleep, a friend unwavering in affection … a holder of a fine tambour, singing for me Abu Nuwas’ poetry: 'And pleasures are only when I see you … lying between skirts and cloaks.' Bakr ibn Khurajah says: At Mary’s Monastery and the Monastery of Zakka … and passing by Thomas and the Archiepiscopal Monastery, where priests recite the Gospel in the ancient house … regarding offerings and crosses … I grieve my yearning heart. Grant me relief before worries overwhelm … and guide me to the right path, for my affairs have narrowed … and You are the refuge from constriction. Abu Al-Faraj said: This poetry is about a young Christian boy from Al-Hirah called ‘Ashir ibn Al-Bara’ Al-Sarraaf, with much poetry about Christian festivals and their markets. Di’bal praised his lines: 'His quiver tied at the waist … as if drawn from my own liver.' He said: 'I wish these two were mine with a hundred verses of my poetry!' Ja’far ibn Qudamah narrated: Maimun ibn Harun told me, who was told by Ishaq Al-Mawsili: When I went out with Al-Wathiq to Najaf, we passed through Al-Hirah and its monasteries, and I saw Mary’s Monastery in Al-Hirah, I admired its location and fine construction, and I said:

What an excellent place for one who seeks his pleasure ... A monastery for Mary built upon the ridge.
A shading shade and water not stagnant ... And cloistered women like dolls, houris.
Al-Wathiq said: "By Allah, we will not take our morning drink tomorrow except in it." He ordered that what was suitable be prepared in it from the night. We went early to it and had our morning drink in it to this voice [song]. He ordered money and distributed it to the people of that monastery, and ordered a reward for me.

**Dayr Marah Maryam in al-Sham**
Dayr Marah Maryam: In al-Sham [Syria], an ancient monastery among its monasteries. Abu al-Faraj said: Al-Husayn bin Yahya told us, from Hammad bin Ishaq, from his father, he said: We stayed with al-Rashid at Dayr Marah Maryam during some of his outings to al-Sham [Syria]. He saw it as a beautiful place, so he became eager for drink and said: "Sing me a song with the meaning of our place." So I sang to him:
What an excellent place for one who seeks his pleasure ... A monastery for Mary built upon the river.
A shading shade and water not stagnant ... And cloistered women like dolls, houris.
He was delighted and drank. He said: "Is this yours?" I said: "No, it is by Ibn Muhriz." He said: "Then you are an echo, conveying what you heard!" I said: "Then I will compose a melody for it." So I composed for it, and sang it. Abu al-Faraj said: The melody of Ibn Muhriz and Ishaq in this poetry, both are from the First Heavy [rhythm].

**Dayr Mar Sargis (Monastery of Saint Sergius)**
Dayr Mar Sargis: In al-Matirah of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq]. My uncle informed me, he said: Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin al-Marzuban bin al-Nayruzan told us, he said: Shaybah bin Hisham told me, he said: Abdullah bin al-Abbas bin al-Fadl bin al-Rabi' became attached to a Christian girl. He had seen her during some of the Christians' festivals, so he would not leave the churches during their festivals out of passion for her. He went out on the festival of Mar Sargis and found her in an orchard next to the church. Before that, he used to correspond with her and make known his love for her, but he could not contact her or meet her except on the road. When he found her, she turned away from him and refused somewhat. Then she appeared to him and sat with him. They ate and drank, and he stayed with her and with women who were with her for a week. Then she departed on a Thursday. Abdullah bin al-Abbas said regarding that and sang in it:
Many a reddish wine from the drink of the Magians ... Babylonian coffee, old wine.
I unveiled it with a flute and a lute ... Before the striking of the deacon on the bell.
And a kohl-eyed gazelle with coquetry ... Magic-eyed, Samaritan, a bride.
We were alone with his goodness, unveiling him ... On a Saturday until the morning of Thursday.
Between roses and fresh myrtle ... In the middle of the orchard of Dayr Mar Sargis.
Bending with the beauty of a gazelle's neck ... With a silvered ebony cross.
How often I kissed the cross on her neck ... Like a crescent crowned with suns.

**Dayr Mar Sargis**
Dayr Mar Sargis, opposite al-Baradan near Baghdad [Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj said: This man has several monasteries [mentioned in his poetry], among them a monastery opposite al-Baradan, at the back of a village called Kadha. Hammad bin Ishaq narrated from Abdullah bin al-Abbas al-Rabi'i, he said: I and Abu al-Nasr al-Basri—a client of Banu Jumah—entered the Church of Mar Sargis. We had ridden with Al-Mu'tasim to hunt. I stopped looking at a girl I loved, and he began looking at an image in the church. He admired it, until that went on for long. Then he recited to me:
An image in a church tempted us ... Allah tempted the one who painted it.
The engraver increased the beauty of salt in its image ... Indeed, he made it radiant.
Her face, I have no doubt, is a temptation ... And so is she to the one who sees her.
I am envious of the priest over her ... Would that other than me had broken it in jest.
He said: So I said to him: "How different we are: I love a human, and you love a stone!" He said to me: "This is jest, and you are serious." Abdullah bin al-Abbas sang this poetry with a beautiful melody I heard from him. People attributed the poetry to him because of his frequent poetry about a Christian woman he loved.

**Dayr al-Matrun**
Dayr al-Matrun
- Al-Qifti mentioned that it—al-Matrun—is an orchard outside Damascus [Syria] called al-Maytur.
- It seems a large distance separates al-Matrun and al-Maytur, indicated by the saying of Arqalah al-Kalbi:
How many a night at al-Matarun I spent ... And a day to al-Maytur while it was rainy.
- Ibn Munir considered it with Darayya among the parks of Damascus [Syria], so he said after listing a group of parks known in his era:
So al-Matrun, then Darayya, then its neighbor ... Then Abil, then the dwellings of Dayr Qanun.
Ibn al-Ruqayyat mentioned it and said:
Al-Faradis became desolate of them, then al-Ghouta ... Possessor of villages and possessor of shades.
Then Dumayr, then al-Matrun, then Hawran [Syria] ... Are wastelands, barren deserts of ruins.

- And Mahasin al-Shawa al-Halabi mentioned it:
O my drinking companion, give me drink at al-Matarun ... A wine that brings the joys of the sad.
- It seems that al-Matarun faded away in the second half of the seventh Hijri century [thirteenth century AD].

**Dayr al-Matrun near Damascus**
Abu Muhammad Hamza bin al-Qasim said: I read on the wall of an orchard in al-Matarun these verses:
I was sleepless at Dayr al-Matrun as if I ... Was a guard for the traveling stars at the end of the night.
And Sirius the Crosser turned away as if it were ... A lamp hung upon the churches.
And Canopus appeared on my right as if it were ... A meteor whose direction the wind blew, a firebrand.
These are ancient verses narrated for Arta'ah bin Suhayyah.

**Dayr Murran**
Dayr Murran
- Al-Bakri said: And there is the Aqabat (pass) of al-Murran, named so because it grows tall, straight trees resembling the Murran (lance wood). And Murran with a Fatha on the Mim is another place, but it is not al-Sham [Syria].
Ibn Munir said:
And what made famous ... The festivals of Palm Sunday (Sha'anin) in Dayr Murran attracts me to the abode of the Romans.
Arqalah al-Kalbi said, longing for this monastery:
And in Dayr Murran is a female vintner ... From the Romans on the day of her Palm Sunday.
She gave me drink upon her desired face ... Thinner and older [wine] than her religion.
- Among the events of this monastery is that Khumarawayh bin Ahmad al-Tuluni was killed—in the year 282 AH—in his palace at Dayr Murran—outside Damascus [Syria].
I say: This is a confirmation of what Habib Zayat established regarding the existence of annexes, taverns, and buildings adjacent to the monastery—see: Al-Khazanah al-Sharqiyyah - Part Two.
- The time of this monastery's ruin is not known, but it is likely that all the news and poems narrated about it after the fifth and sixth Hijri centuries should be attributed to the locality of Murran. It appears that the traces of the monastery remained visible until after the eleventh century, as inferred from verses by Abd al-Rahman ibn Hamza narrated by al-Muhibbi.

**Dayr Murran near Damascus**
Ali bin Sulayman al-Ahfash informed me, he said: Al-Sukkari and Al-Mubarrad told me from Dimadh Abu Ghassan, whose name is Rafi' bin Salamah, from Abu Ubaydah:
That Muawiyah sent an army to the land of the Romans to raid the summer campaign. Smallpox afflicted them, so most of the Muslims died. His son Yazid was drinking his morning draught at Dayr Murran with his wife "Umm Kulthum." The news of them reached him, so he said:
If I reclined on carpets drinking the morning draught ... At Dayr Murran, with Umm Kulthum with me,
Then I do not care what their armies encountered ... At al-Fadhaqadhunah of fever and smallpox.
His poetry reached his father, so he said: "Yes, by Allah, he shall surely join them so that what afflicted them may afflict him." So he went out until he joined them and raided until he reached Constantinople [Istanbul, Turkey]. He looked at two built domes upon which were brocade clothes. If the charge was for the Muslims, sounds of tambourines, drums, and flutes rose from one of them. And if the charge was for the Romans, it rose from the other. He asked about them, and it was said to him: "This is the daughter of the King of the Romans, and that is the daughter of Jabalah bin al-Ayham; each one of them shows joy for what her tribe does." He said: "By Allah, I will surely grieve them." Then he aligned the army and charged until he defeated the Romans and forced them into the city. He struck the gate of Constantinople with an iron mace that was in his hand and smashed it until it was pierced. A gold plate was struck over it, and it remains on it to this day.
Abu al-Faraj al-Isbahani said: Dayr Murran is in an area of Damascus [Syria] on a hill overlooking farms and pleasant, joyful gardens. Harun al-Rashid stayed at it, caroused in it, and drank. Al-Husayn bin al-Dahhak al-Khali' was with al-Rashid when he stayed at it, so he said to him: "By my life, say some poetry about it!" So he said verses regarding it, among them:
O Dayr Murran, may you not be stripped of inhabitants ... You have stirred sorrow for me, O Dayr Murrana.
May Murran and its dweller be watered and tended ... Oh, how lovely is the resident in the monastery, whoever it was.
Urge the wine, for the cup is brimming ... From what stirs the causes of longing at times.
Al-Rashid ordered Amr bin Banah to sing two melodies in it, one Hazaj and the other Raml.

Ishaq al-Mawsili recounted from his father, who said: Al-Rashid passed by Dayr Murran and admired it and was pleased by its overlooking of beautiful orchards and delightful, joyful gardens. So he camped at it and ordered that light food be brought. He ate and drank, and called for the drinking companions and singers. The owner of the monastery came out to him; he was a very old, decrepit sheikh. He stood before him, prayed for him, and asked his permission to bring him food from the monastery. He permitted him to do that. So he brought him elegant, concise foods in clean vessels. It was of the utmost beauty and goodness. He ate much of it and found it good. He ordered the sheikh to sit, so he sat before him. Al-Rashid turned his face to him and asked him, so he spoke to him, and he found his conversation witty. Then he said: "Did anyone from Banu Umayyah stay with you in this monastery?" He said: "Yes, may Allah reform my master the Commander of the Faithful. Al-Walid bin Yazid stayed with me here, and with him was his brother al-Ghamr. They sat in this place where my master the Commander of the Faithful sat. I presented food to them, so they ate, drank, sang, and were merry. When the wine took hold of them, Al-Walid leaped into that basin—which was full of wine—and drank from it directly (sipped). His brother al-Ghamr did the same, until they became intoxicated and slept in their places. When Al-Walid recovered from his intoxication, he ordered the basin to be filled for me with dirhams. Then they departed." Al-Rashid looked at it (meaning the cup), and lo, he could not drink its fill. He said: "Banu Umayyah refused but to precede us to pleasures, a precedence in which no one surpasses them." Then he ordered the removal of the wine, rode immediately, and departed. He ordered a magnificent reward for the monastery dweller.
Al-Suli told me, he said: Yazid bin Muhammad al-Muhallabi told us, he said: Amr bin Banah told us, he said: We went out with Al-Mu'tasim to al-Sham [Syria] when he raided. We stopped on our way at Dayr Murran—which is a monastery on a high overlooking hill, beneath which are meadows and beautiful waters. Al-Mu'tasim camped in it, ate, and became eager for drink, so he called for us. When we drank some cups, he said to Husayn bin al-Dahhak: "Where is this place compared to the outskirts of Baghdad [Iraq]!" He said: "Nowhere, O Commander of the Faithful! By Allah, some of the thickets and reed beds there are better than here." He said: "You spoke the truth, by Allah. And upon that, say some verses in which Amr may sing." He said: "As for saying something describing this area with good, I do not think my tongue will utter it. But I will speak longing for Baghdad." He laughed and said: "Say what you wish." So he said:
O Dayr Madyan, may you not be stripped of inhabitants ... You stirred sickness for me, O Dayr Madyana.
Does your priest have knowledge to inform us ... Or how does the face of patience aid the one who departed?
Urge the wine, for the cup is brimming ... From what stirs the causes of longing at times.
May Karkhaya and its dweller be watered and tended ... And for the little garden in al-Rawha, whoever was there.
Al-Mu'tasim admired it, and he ordered me and Mukhariq, so we sang in it. He drank to that until he became intoxicated, and ordered rewards for the group.

**Dayr Marmari (Monastery of Marmari)**
Dayr Marmari in Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq]: It is in Surra Man Ra'a, at the Bridge of Wasif. Around it are vineyards and trees. It was populated with many monks, and people of amusement frequented it. Regarding it, Al-Fadl bin al-Abbas bin al-Ma'mun says:
I wore out the horses of my pleasures in Surra Man Ra [Samarra] ... And I attained from it my soul's desire and my needs.
I inhabited in it the places of amusement, immersing myself ... In revelry between rivers and gardens.
At Dayr Marmar, as we revive the morning draught in it ... And work the cup in it in the evenings.
Between the bells and the sanctification at times ... And sometimes between lutes and flutes.
And how many a slender, flirtatious gazelle in it ... Hunts us with Babylonian glances.
- Al-Suli told me, he said: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ishaq al-Khurasani told me, he said: Al-Fadl bin al-Abbas bin al-Ma'mun told me, he said: I was with Al-Mu'tazz hunting. He became separated from the procession, and I and Yunus bin Bugha were with him. We were near the Bridge of Wasif, and there was a monastery there with a monastery dweller whom I knew and who knew me. He was clean, witty, with pleasant manners and speech. Al-Mu'tazz complained of thirst. I said: "O Commander of the Faithful, in this monastery is a monastery dweller I know who is light-spirited and is not without cold water. Do you see fit that we turn to him?" He said: "Yes." So we came, and he brought out cold water for us. He asked me about Al-Mu'tazz and Yunus, so I said: "Young men from the sons of the soldiers." He said: "Nay, two escapees from the Houris of Paradise." I said to him: "This is not in your religion." He said: "It is now in my religion." Al-Mu'tazz laughed. The monastery dweller said to me: "Will you eat something?" I said: "Yes." So he brought out sandwiches, bread, and clean condiments. We ate the best meal. He came to us with the most curious potash (cleaning agent). Al-Mu'tazz found him amusing and said to me: "Ask him between you and him: Whom do you love to be with you of these two, never parting from you?" I said to him [the question]. He said: "Both of them, and dates." Al-Mu'tazz laughed until he leaned against the wall of the monastery.

I said to the monastery dweller: "You must choose." He said: "The choice, by Allah, in this is destruction, and Allah has not created a mind that distinguishes between these two!" The procession caught up with them, and the monastery dweller was terrified. Al-Mu'tazz said to him: "By my life, do not cease from what we were in, for I am a master to those there and a friend to those here." So we joked for an hour, then he ordered five hundred thousand dirhams for him. He said: "By Allah, I will not accept it except on a condition." He said: "And what is it?" He said: "That the Commander of the Faithful answers my invitation with whomever he wishes." He said: "That is yours." So we agreed on a day we would come to him. He left no limit [in generosity] and established for the whole procession what was needed. He brought us the children of the Christians to serve us. Al-Mu'tazz gave him a magnificent gift that day, and he did not cease visiting him, staying with him, and drinking for the duration of his life.

**Dayr al-Mazuq**
Dayr al-Mazuq, and it is said Dayr Ibn al-Mazuq. It is ancient, on the outskirts of al-Hirah [Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj mentioned it and recited for Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman al-Tharwani regarding it and Dayr Fathiyun:
I said to him while the stars were leaning ... On the night of Easter, at the first of the magic (pre-dawn),
Do you have a desire for Mar Fathiyun and for ... Dayr Ibn Mazuq, without falling short?
This breeze overflows from the side of ... Al-Sham [Syria] and the flow of dew is on the trees.
And we ask the earth about its cheerfulness ... And its covenant with spring and rain.
O what goodness and smelling of a scent ... Like musk coming with the breath of the magic.
In drinking wine and hearing a good female [singer] ... Distracting you between the tongue and the string.
He said: Dayr Fathiyun is at the bottom of the Najaf [Iraq]. And Dayr Ibn Mazuq is opposite the Palace of Abd al-Masih at the top of the Najaf. Al-Tharwani says about it:
You turn the gaze of your eye from afar ... Resembling affection and threat.
You admit with the gaze of your eye to me of connection ... And your action to me admits denial.
You make me doubt, and I know that this ... Is a passion between sympathy and avoidance.
Your passion is a passion renewed by the nights ... And it does not wear out with the passing of epochs.
He also said:
The drink returned to an intoxicated morning drinker ... Who woke up to drink it while the rooster had not crowed.
And the night is in an army whose lightning flashes are many ... From the stars, and the light of the morning has not appeared.
And life is no life unless you act early for it ... With a reddish wine that kills the worry of the soul with joy.
Until he who spent the night drinking it remains ... With no departure in him, strutting like the merry one.
Al-Tharwani longed for it from Baghdad [Iraq], so he said:
Dayr al-Hariq and the Church of al-Mazuq ... Between the pond and the dome of al-Sinniq.
Are more desirable to me than al-Sarat and its goodness ... At the morning, and than the darkness of the patrician.
O friend! Avoid blame; do you not see ... How ugly your blame is to me, while you are my friend?

**Dayr Najran (Monastery of Najran)**
Dayr Najran: It is in Yemen [historically Yemen, currently Najran, Saudi Arabia], and the Arabs call it the Kaaba of Najran. It belongs to the family of Abd al-Madan bin al-Dayyan from Banu al-Harith bin Ka'b. From it came the people who wanted to engage in Mubahala (mutual imprecation) with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Abu al-Faraj al-Isbahani mentioned it and said: It belonged to the family of Abd al-Madan, the masters of Banu al-Harith. He said: People of three houses from Yemen were Christians, competing in churches and their attire and the beauty of their building: the family of al-Mundhir in al-Hirah [Iraq], Ghassan in al-Sham [Syria], and Banu al-Harith bin Ka'b in Najran [Saudi Arabia]. Their monasteries would be in places with many trees, gardens, and ponds, with lofty construction. They made their utensils of gold and silver, their curtains of brocade, put mosaics in their walls, and gold in their ceilings. Banu al-Harith remained upon that until Islam came. Regarding this Kaaba of theirs, Al-A'sha, Al-A'sha of Qays bin Tha'labah, said:
And the Kaaba of Najran is a duty upon you ... Until you make the camels kneel at its doors.
We visit Yazid and Abd al-Masih ... And Qays, and they are the best of its lords.
When the Hibarat (Yemeni cloaks) are twisted on them ... And they drag the bottoms of their fringes.
And our witness is the roses and the jasmine ... And the female singers with their flutes.
And a tireless worker binds us ... So which of the three did he criticize?
He said: In this poetry is good singing, which Jahza took from Banan.

**Dayr Hind al-Sughra (Monastery of Hind the Younger)**
Dayr Hind al-Sughra in al-Hirah [Iraq]. Abu al-Faraj al-Isbahani said: In al-Hirah is the monastery of Hind bint al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir. Khalid bin al-Walid entered upon her and said to her: "Submit [to Islam] so that I may marry you to a noble, original man from the Muslims who resembles you in your lineage." She said: "As for my religion, I have no desire to leave it, nor do I seek a substitute for it. As for marriage, if there were any remainder [of youth] in me, I would not have married nor desired it, so how [can I] when I am an old woman, a skull of today or tomorrow." He said to her:
- "Ask me a need I may fulfill for you." She said:

- "My greatest need is these Christians who are in your protection." He said: "Yes, this is an obligation upon us in our religion; our Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded us with it. Is there other than this?" She said: "I am in this monastery adjacent to these decaying bones of the people of my house and my religion until I join them." He ordered money and clothing for her, but she said: "I have no need for anything of what you offered. I have two slaves who cultivate a farm from which I get nourishment that sustains my last breath, and I spend what remains on the weak of the people of my religion. I have counted your speech as action, and your promise as cash. But hear from me a supplication that used to be prayed for our kings: 'May a hand that became poor after wealth be grateful to you, and may a hand that became rich after poverty not reach you. And may Allah make your kindness hit its places, and may He not remove a blessing from a generous one except that He makes you a cause for returning it to him'."
This monastery is near Banu Abdullah bin Darim in Kufa [Iraq], next to the trench, in a pleasant place. Several poets have mentioned it, among them Ma'n bin Zaida al-Shaybani, and his home was there. He says about it:
O would that I knew, shall I spend a night ... At Dayr Hind while the beloved is near?
So desires are fulfilled and loved ones are met ... And a moist branch of joy puts forth leaves.
He also says about it:
If my night in Baghdad [Iraq] is long, then perhaps ... It is seen in the south of the Monastery as short.
Abu al-Faraj said: Al-Mughira bin Shu'bah entered upon her when she had gone blind. He conversed with her for a long time, then proposed to her. She laughed and said: "A one-eyed old man, and a blind old woman! By the Cross, you did not want me seeking offspring, nor out of desire for wealth, nor passion for beauty, but you wanted to say: 'I married the daughter of al-Nu'man!' Depart guided." So he departed saying:
You perceived what I wished my soul in private ... Goodness to you, O daughter of al-Nu'man.
You have returned his mind to Al-Mughira ... Indeed, kings are of sharp minds.
O Hind, indeed you have spoken the truth, so refrain ... And truth is the best speech of man.
I am a believer in your swearing by the Cross ... And the Crucifix is the truest oath of the monks.
After that, the youth of Kufa [Iraq] used to go out to this monastery picnicking, eating in its gardens and drinking. Abu Hayyan says about this Dayr Hind:
O Dayr Hind, you have become a comfort to me ... And you were not; you were to me, O monastery, a place of comfort.
May your shade be watered, a shade I used to frequent ... In it, I associate with a priest and a deacon.
Of old, and the times of joy were ... And of happiness in it, O people, like weddings.
I do not lack amusement in the corners of its temple ... Nor do I return the cup to the cupbearer in it.

**Dayr Hind al-Kubra (Monastery of Hind the Elder)**
Dayr Hind al-Kubra in al-Hirah [Iraq] is a monastery built by Hind the Elder, mother of Amr bin Hind. She is Hind bint al-Harith bin Amr bin Hujr Akil al-Murar al-Kindi. Written on its front was: "Hind bint al-Harith bin Amr bin Hujr, the Queen daughter of Kings, and mother of the King Amr bin al-Mundhir, the maidservant of the Messiah, and mother of His servant, and maidservant of His servant, built this church in the time of the King of Kings Khosrow Anushirvan, and in the time of Ephraim the Bishop. So may the God for whom she built this house forgive her sin, and have mercy on her and her son, and accept them and raise them to the establishment of truth, and may the God be with her and with her son for the eternal eternity."
Abu al-Faraj said: Jaafar bin Qudamah told me, from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Malik al-Khuza'i from his father, he said: I entered with Yahya bin Khalid - Dayr Hind the First, when we went out with al-Rashid to al-Hirah [Iraq]. He had intended it to picnic in it and see the ruins of al-Mundhir. He saw the grave of her father al-Nu'man, and her grave beside it. Then he went out to the other Dayr Hind, which is the larger one, and it is on the edge of the Najaf [Iraq]. He saw on the side of its wall an inscription. He ordered a ladder, so it was brought, and ordered some of his companions to climb to it. And lo, it was:
Indeed, the Banu al-Mundhir have passed away generally ... Where the monk built the church.
Their pungent musk wafts ... and ambergris that the collector gathers.
And silk and linen were their clothes ... No weaver wove wool for them.
And glory and kingship were established for them ... And wine whose pouring vessel flows.
They became such that no seeker hopes from them ... Any good, nor does a fearer fear them.
As if they were a toy in it ... With which the rider traveled to where?
So they became in the layers of the earth ... After a bliss that was constant for them.
The worst of remainders is he who remains of them ... Fewness and humiliation, his luck is disappointed.
He said: Yahya wept when this poetry was read, and said: "This is the way of the world." And he turned away from that direction of his.

**Chapter Two**
**News of Unknown Monasteries**
Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Ayyub told us, he said Abdullah bin Muslim told us: It reached me that Abu al-Tamhan al-Qayni was asked—and he was a profligate ruiner—"What is the lowest of your sins?" He said: "The night of the monastery." It was said: "And what is the night of the monastery?" He said: "I stayed with a nun, so I ate a Tafishal (stew) with pork at her place, drank from her wine, committed adultery with her, stole her cloak, and then left her."
Harun bin Muhammad al-Zayyat said: Hammad bin Ishaq al-Mawsili told me from his father: That al-Gharid heard the voices of monks at night in a monastery of theirs and admired them. Some of those with him said to him: "O Abu Yazid; craft a melody like this voice." So he crafted the like of it in his melody:
O Umm Bakr, your love is apparent ... Do not cut me off, for I am departing early.
The departure has become serious and my companions have urged me ... And I want an enjoyment of provisions.
The poetry is by Sa'id bin Abd al-Rahman bin Hassan bin Thabit al-Ansari.
- Al-Hasan bin Ali informed me, he said Ibn Mahrawayh told us, he said Ubayd Allah bin Ammar told me, he said Ubayd Allah bin Ahmad bin al-Harith al-Qurashi told me, he said al-Abbas bin al-Walid told us, he said Damrah told us:
Abd al-Wahhab bin Ibrahim the Imam went out one day to some monasteries and stayed in one, while he was governor of al-Ramla [Palestine]. He asked the owner of the monastery: "Did anyone from Banu Umayyah stay with you?" He said: "Yes, Al-Walid bin Yazid and Muhammad bin Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik stayed with me." He said: "So what did they do?" He said: "They drank in that place, and indeed I saw them drinking from their vessels. Then one of them said to his companion: 'Come, let us drink from this Jurn (large stone basin)'—and he pointed to a great basin of marble—He said: 'I will do it.' So they did not cease passing it between them and drinking from it until they were intoxicated." Abd al-Wahhab said to a black client of his: "Bring it." Damrah said: I saw him, and he was described as strong, going to move it, but he could not. The monk said: "By Allah, I saw them passing it to each other, and each one of them would fill it for his companion, lift it, and drink it without caring."
Abu Hashisha said: Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi heard voices of my singing from Muhammad bin al-Harith bin Buskhunnar and Amr bin Banah, and he admired them and his slave girls took them. He said: "The Tanbur (long-necked lute) is all invalid; if any of it is truth, then it is this." He desired to hear me. I feared him with a great fear and said: "If he is pleased with me, that will not increase me, and if he is not pleased with me, a stigma will remain on me for the rest of time." He used to request me from Muhammad bin al-Harith bin Buskhunnar specifically, and from Ishaq bin Amr bin Bazi', so I used to flee from them. Until we were present in Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Iraq], and I was in those days devoted to Abu Ahmad bin al-Rashid. We were in tents, and we had not inhabited the houses yet. The messenger of Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi came to Abu Ahmad bin al-Rashid, conveyed greetings to him, and said: "Your uncle says to you: 'The tricks have exhausted me regarding this malicious one, and I love to hear him while he flees from me. So I would love for you to send him to me and let Rabrab be with him to comfort him'."
Abu Ahmad said to me: "You must go to my uncle." I strove with every effort for him to excuse me, but he refused. When I saw that it was something inevitable, I put on my clothes and went to him. He was staying in the monastery. He welcomed and brought [me] near, and put me completely at ease. Rabrab was with me. He called for date wine (Nabidh) and ordered servants of his, elders, so they sat with me, drank, and gave me drink. He offered me by every trick to sing, but I feared him with intense fear and was tongue-tied. I drank a Ratl (large cup). He called for three slave girls; they came out and sat. He said to them: "Say." They said:
How is my trick when you do not connect ... My patience has run out and tricks are few.
If my body is wasted by your love ... Then my heart relies upon you.
The poetry is by Khalid the Scribe and the singing is by Abu Hashisha, Raml [rhythm]. He used to call it "The Monastic" (Al-Rahbani); he created it to a melody from the melodies of the Christians he heard from monks at night repeating it, so he created it upon that. One of them sang it, so I lost my mind, and I heard something I had never heard the like of. He said: "O my friend, is this yours?" I said: "Yes, may Allah reform the Prince." A trembling seized me. He said to them: "Say." They said:
My Lord, what is the matter with me and passion ... What is the matter with this passion and with me.
My eye is confused, which loved ... The beauty of my heart and what it contained.
The poetry is by Khalid, and the singing is by Abu Hashisha, Raml. She sang it even more wondrously than the first. He said: "O my friend, is this yours?" I said: "Yes, O my master." He said: "Thus we took them from Muhammad bin al-Harith." Then he drank another Ratl. I said to myself: "The man invited you to hear you or to make you hear." I strengthened my resolve and sang to him with poetry by Khalid the Scribe, which is:
If your heart persists in mentioning him ... And your beloved persists in abandoning him.
It has bequeathed the eye long weeping ... And the heart is mighty against patience for him.
If passion for him takes away the heart ... Then your body, no doubt, is on his trail.

And which lover has passion treated harshly ... With long remembrance, yet did not wear him out?
He began repeating the first verse and the last verse and said: "Do not go out, O my friend, to another." I did not cease repeating it to him until he drank a third. I rested for an hour, drank a Ratl, and my soul felt good. Then he asked me to repeat, so I sang his melody to him, differently than the first. He looked at me and laughed and did not say anything. He drank a fourth Ratl. Sunset came, so he said to me: "O my friend, I do not doubt that I have made my son lonely for you, so go in the protection of Allah." I departed flying with joy. When I came to Abu Ahmad and he looked at me from afar, he said: "Wheat or barley?" I said: "Nay, sesame and honey. escape despite the nose of the one who is spiteful." He said: "Woe to you, do you think I do not know your merit? But I loved to seek the help of his opinion on my opinion of you." I told him the story, and that pleased him. He was not satisfied until he sent Muhammad bin Rashid the strangler to him secretly, asking him about me. He said: "I did not think there was anyone like him in his craft."
Abu al-Hasan Jahza said: Khalid the Scribe said to me: I entered some monasteries one day, and suddenly I was with a young man bound in shackles, beautiful of face. I greeted him, and he returned the greeting to me and said: "Who are you?" I said: "Khalid bin Yazid." He said: "The author of the delicate pieces?" I said: "Yes!" He said: "If you see fit to relieve me with some of what you recite to me of your poetry, then do so." So I recited to him:
I sipped from her lips a wine ... And kissed from her cheek a pomegranate blossom.
And I embraced from her a shifting sand dune ... And a moist branch and a moon that illuminated.
And I saw from her light in the darkness ... For every place in the night, a day.
He said: "You have done well! May Allah not break your mouth (teeth)." Then he said: "Complete for me these two verses:
Many a night longer than the breath of the lover ... In length, I spent in wailing.
And a conversation more delicious than the look of the lover ... I exchanged for bad blame."
By Allah, I worked my mind, but I was not able to complete them!

**Chapter Three**
**Festivals of Palm Sunday (Sha'anin)**
Ali bin Harun bin al-Munajjim informed me from Ziryab, she said: I visited Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz on the day of Sha'anin (Palm Sunday). He was pleased with my arrival and composed immediately a melody to the poetry of Abdullah bin al-Abbas al-Rabi'i, for which he has a Hazaj [rhythm], which is:
I have wounds in my heart from the gazelle ... So leave blame, for blame is meanness.
How lovely is the day of Sha'anin and what ... I attained in it of joy, if it would last.
- The poetry is by Abdullah bin al-Abbas, and his melody in it is Hazaj.
She said: So Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz composed a Hazaj for the second verse, and a verse after it which he added to it, which is:
My master visited me in it for an hour ... Would that he, by Allah, as long as I live, would stay.
The melody of Ibn al-Mu'tazz in "How lovely is the day of Sha'anin" and this verse is Light Raml, and it is among the limits (best) of the songs he composed. And among his composition in which he was witty and elegant:
My sleeve crowded his sleeve so they twisted ... My heart agreed with his heart so they equaled.
And long did they taste passion so they were cauterized ... O cool of the eye and O my worry and O.
He intended here by his saying "and O" what people say in imitating the thing with which they address a person of beautiful or ugly, so they say: I said to him O my master and O my lord and O O, and likewise its opposite, to dispense by indicating with this call instead of the explanation. The melody of Ibn al-Mu'tazz in this is Hazaj.
My uncle told me, he said: Ahmad bin al-Marzuban told me, he said: Shaybah bin Hisham told me, he said: Abdullah bin al-Abbas loved a Christian girl. He could not reach her nor see her except when she went out to the church. So we went out one day with him to the Sha'anin. He stood until she came. He saw her and then recited to us for himself and sang in it after that:
If you are a possessor of medicine, then treat me ... And do not blame, for blame incites me.
O a look that left a fatal passion ... From a fawn on the day of Sha'anin.
And a look from a herd of wild cows' eyes ... Who went out in the best adornment.
They went out walking to a picnic ... Young women among the orchards.
Belted with their belts (Zunnar) ... And life is what is under the belts.
The melody of Abdullah bin al-Abbas in this poetry is Hazaj.
